rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, adaptability to a broad range of habitat types and tolerance of disturbance, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category, and the population presently appears to be stable.
habitat: The Gold Dust Day Gecko can be found in a variety of habitats, but is absent from denser forest regions. Palms and banana trees are the preferred vegetation, but they can also be found on traveller's palm (Ravenala madagascariensis), smaller deciduous trees, and often in gardens and on houses. It is an egg-laying species.
threats: There are no threats to this very adaptable species. There has been a low level of collection for the international pet trade but this probably does not constitute a threat to the species, which is both abundant in the wild and bred commercially in captivity.
population: This species is considered very abundant within its Malagasy range, especially in the Sambirano region of the northwest (Glaw and Vences 2007). There is no recent information on its abundance from other islands.
range: This species is native to northern Madagascar. The nominate subspecies is also found in Anjouan and the French Department of Mayotte, both within the Comoros archipelago, where it is presumed to represent a recent introduction (Rocha et al. 2007). It has been recorded from the coral islands of Farquhar and Providence in the southern Seychelles; as these are the closest of the Seychelles islands to Madagascar it is unclear whether this represents a natural colonization or a human introduction (Gerlach 2008). It has also been introduced to Réunion (N. Cole pers. comm. July 2011), Hawaii (Rocha et al. 2007) and French Polynesia (Ota and Ineich 2006), and recently also to Mauritius (N. Cole pers. comm. July 2011). On Madagascar the nominate subspecies has been recorded from a range of sites including Ambanja (Rocha et al. 2009), Ambilobe (Glaw and Vences 2007), Antalaha (Rocha et al. 2009), Antsohiy (Glaw and Vences 2007), Cap Est (Glaw and Vences 2007), Lokobe (Andreone et al. 2003), Manongarivo (Raxworthy 1988), Marojejy (Raselimanana et al. 2000), Nosy Faly (Glaw and Vences 2007), Nosy Komba (Glaw and Vences 2007), Nosy Mitsio (Andreone et al. 2003) and Sambava (Glaw and Vences 2007).  The subspecies P. l. angularis occurs along the northwestern coastal plain of Madagascar.
useTrade: There has been a small international pet trade, with animals both collected from the wild and bred in captivity.
conservationActions: The gold dust day gecko presumably occurs in some protected areas in Madagascar. It is included on Appendix II of CITES. The origin of the Seychelles population requires clarification.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern on the basis that it is widespread, common in degraded habitats, and subject to no threats.
habitat: This lizard is cosmopolitan in the Guinean humid tropics, occurring in forest, moist savanna, and varied anthropogenic habitats including plantations, gardens and farmland (Trape et al. 2012, Spawls et al. 2002). Within Ethiopia it has been recorded from a range of habitats, including humid savanna to cool grassland, woodland clearings, dry woodland and bush (Nachisar National Park - Largen and Spawls 2010). It is particularly associated with human structures, but is also found on the ground and in low vegetation (Trape et al. 2012), including waterside bushes along the shore of Lake Victoria (Spawls et al. 2002). In coastal areas it can be found on coconut palms (Spawls et al. 2002). This diurnal skink feeds on arthropods and slugs (Trape et al. 2012). It is oviparous, laying between six and eight eggs (Largen and Spawls 2010).
threats: There are no threats to this widespread and adaptable lizard.
population: This skink is common on and around varied human structures, including walls, bridges and gutters (Trape et al. 2012). It is a common species in East Africa. In forested southeast Guinea this lizard is much rarer than the sympatric Trachylepis affinis and appears to be more closely-associated with forest, however, the reverse appears to be true in Cameroon (Böme et al. 2011) and on the Jos Plateau in Nigeria (J.-F. Trape pers comm. 2012). The population is stable.
range: This very widespread species ranges through humid sub-Saharan Africa from Guinea to Angola, through parts of Zambia, Malawi and Mozambique, including all territories in the Guinean climatic zone of West Africa (Trape et al. 2012). It ranges as far northeast as Ethiopia and southern Somalia, being known from the Mogadishu, Middle Juba and Lower Juba regions of the latter country (Largen and Spawls 2010, Lanza 1990). Also recorded from Europa Island, Mozambique Channel Islands of the French Southern Territories. It tends to be localized within its extensive range (Largen and Spawls 2010). In East Africa records are associated with rivers, the shores of Lake Victoria, and the flanks of the Rift Valley (Spawls et al. 2002). It occurs inland in Tanzania to the Usambara and Udzungwa Mountains, but is absent from inland areas of Kenya aside from a doubtful record from Kora National Park (Spawls et al. 2002). It is reported to reach elevations of up to 2,300 m asl in East Africa (Largen and Spawls 2010), and 2,550 m asl in West Africa.
useTrade: There is unlikely to be any significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures required for this species. Due to its wide range, it undoubtedly occurs in many protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species is known to survive on four small islets following severe historical declines and local extinctions, most recently the loss of the Flat Island subpopulation in 2011. The population is presently stable following the removal of invasive mammalian predators from the largest subpopulation on Gunner's Quoin and the species is subject to ongoing monitoring. The population is exposed to predation by exotic ants and reintroduced native predators; it is not thought to be at immediate risk of extinction so long as ongoing conservation management continues. This situation will rapidly change should Gunner's Quoin be invaded by invasive predators/competitors, such as House Geckos, rats, shrews or wolf snakes, which have so far been prevented by conservation actions, but remains a plausible future threat, potentially facilitated by illegal visits to the islands where the species survives. The restricted range of the Lesser Night Gecko on the four small islets makes the species potentially highly susceptible to stochastic events including fire and storms.
habitat: The Lesser Night Gecko is nocturnal and insectivorous (Arnold and Jones 1994, Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2009), although animals also consume nectar. The species is mostly found in coastal habitats on cliffs and in areas of large rock piles and bedrock with multiple deep crevices and cavities. Geckos also occupy dense mats of the native grass, Zoysia tenuifolia and areas of deep leaf litter and root systems of native and non-native vegetation. They will climb native and non-native trees and palms, taking refuge under loose bark and within palm crowns. They are highly cryptic and their base colour varies to match the colour of their habitat (Cole 2009). The average total body length and weight of adult geckos is 6 cm and 0.77 g, respectively, and their tail makes up half of the body length (Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2009). Female geckos are generally larger and bulkier than males. Larger reptilian predators, such as the endemic Keel-scaled Boa Casarea dussumieri and Telfair’s Skink Leiolopisma telfairii, which have been reintroduced to Gunner’s Quoin, predate the gecko and they are occasionally taken by the native land crab Geograpsus grayi (N. Cole pers. obs.). The geckos are highly vocal, producing a loud repeated metallic ‘tchick’ sound, from which they can be easily identified from all other non-Nactus gecko species in Mauritius (Arnold and Jones 1994, Cole 2009). The geckos call mostly at dusk and dawn, which has been used in combination with visual searches to survey the Mascarenes and outer islands for night gecko populations (Cole 2005, N. Cole unpublished data). The geckos can reproduce throughout the year, but gravid geckos are mostly encountered between June and February, with most hatchlings found from January to April (N. Cole unpublished data). Females lay one egg at a time and as often as every 25 days (Goble and Goetz 2011). At a temperature of 24/27 ºC (Night/Day) eggs hatched between 102–106 days and at 25/29ºC (Night/Day) eggs hatched between 82–95 days (Goble and Goetz 2011). Geckos reach maturity at eight months (Goble and Goetz 2011). Longevity is thought to be approximately four years (Goble and Goetz 2011), but individuals on Ile Marianne, in the absence of predators, have been repeatedly detected for up to seven years (MRRP unpublished data).
threats: Historically, the Lesser Night Gecko has undergone a catastrophic decline, following the arrival of humans and the resulting loss of habitat and introduction of numerous non-native species from the 1500s (Cheke and Hume 2008). The introduced House Gecko Hemidactylus frenatus has been shown to predate and exclude Lesser Night Geckos from shared refuges, potentially exposing them to higher levels of predation and severe weather (Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2005). The House Gecko also has the potential to outcompete Lesser Night Geckos for shared food resources (Cole 2005). The Lesser Night Gecko does not persist in the presence of the House Gecko (Arnold and Jones 1994), but previously survived on Flat Island, where House Geckos were present but excluded from the powdery rock which the night geckos occupied (Cole et al. 2005). The invasive Big-headed Ant Pheidole megacephala predates and injures Lesser Night Geckos, although the extent of their impact is currently unknown. There are risks of further ant species invasions, such as Tropical Fire Ants Solenopsis geminata, which are known to predate the Lesser Night Geckos (Cole 2005). The invasion of Flat Island by the Musk Shrew in 2010 and the rapid extinction of the islet’s Lesser Night Gecko population, demonstrates the threat posed by this invasive predatory mammal. Not all invasive predatory mammals pose the same threat, as the Lesser Night Geckos survived on Gunner’s Quoin in the presence of Norway Rats for approximately 150 years, prior to rat eradication in 1995 (Cheke and Hume 2008). Both the Lesser Night Gecko and Durrell’s Night Gecko Nactus durrellorum, which had been experimentally released on Ilot Chat (0.029 ha) in 2006 to test the co-existence of the two species, did not survive the invasion of a single Ship Rat Rattus rattus in 2007 (Cole et al., 2009). Other potential invasive alien species in Mauritius that are a threat to the Lesser Night Gecko and known to cause rapid declines and the extirpation of small endemic terrestrial reptiles include the Indian Wolf Snake Lycodon aulicus and Tailless Tenrec Tenrec ecaudatus (Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2009, Goder et al. 2015, MRRP unpublished data). The rate of offshore island invasion events is approximately three non-native fauna incursions per year, several of which have posed a significant threat to terrestrial biodiversity (Cole and Payne 2015). In most cases, staff of the Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust, Mauritian Wildlife Foundation and National Parks and Conservation Service through the Mauritius Reptile Recovery Programme have prevented non-native species incursions from establishing, although the risk of species arriving, for which there are no current methods for removal (such as house geckos or musk shrews) is high. All of the islets where the Lesser Night Gecko survives are closed to public access, but trespassers frequently access Gunner’s Quoin, Ile Marianne and Ilot Vacoas. Illegal access to the islets poses a risk of species introduction, but also from trampling, where crevices in which the geckos take refuge and deposit their eggs are crushed under foot. On Ilot Vacoas, the small area of rock occupied by the geckos is often covered in discarded charcoal or hot cooking oil from trespassers barbequing on the islet. Given the restricted range of the species, invasive predators and competitors, extreme weather, intense cyclones and fire all represent a significant threat to the survival of the species.
population: The global population of Lesser Night Gecko is estimated at approximately 18,000 individuals and currently considered stable. The largest subpopulation is found on Gunner’s Quoin, where in 2018, 37 line transects walked at night using distance sampling methodology estimated the population size at 16,753 (95% CI, range 11,861–23,663) adults (MRRP, unpublished data). Annual surveys of the subpopulation on Gunner’s Quoin since 2006 shows some fluctuation between 12,000 and 18,000 individuals, but overall the population is stable. Pigeon House Rock was last surveyed in 2004 (Cole 2005), where the population size has been extrapolated from encounter rate survey data to be approximately 200 individuals. The Pigeon House Rock subpopulation is considered to be stable, due to the remoteness and isolation of the islet from human disturbance. The gecko population size on Ilot Vacoas was estimated, through capture mark recapture method, at 237 (95% CI, range 136–413) adults in 2018 (MRRP, unpublished data). Annual surveys of the population on Ilot Vacoas since 2006, shows some fluctuation between 200 and 400 individuals, but overall the population is stable. The translocated subpopulation on Ile Marianne was estimated, through the capture mark recapture method, at 528 (95% CI, range 373–747) adults in 2019 (MRRP, unpublished data), following the release of 75 captive bred and wild caught individuals, originating from Ilot Vacoas in 2011 (MRRP 2011).
range: This species is endemic to Mauritius and once thought to have been found throughout much of Mauritius and its surrounding islets. The introduction of non-native predators and competitors from the 16th century (Cheke and Hume 2008) has led to a catastrophic reduction in the gecko’s geographic range (Arnold and Jones 1994, Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2005, MRRP (Mauritius Reptile Recovery Programme)  2011a). The species was discovered in 1982 on Gunner’s Quoin (0.70 km2; Bullock et al. 1985), but had a severely restricted range here due to the presence of introduced Norway Rats Rattus norvegicus. By 1993, the species was considered extinct (Arnold and Jones 1994) and was erroneously (as no captive population existed) listed in a 1996 Red List assessment as ‘Extinct in the Wild’. In 1996, one year post rat eradication, the gecko population was rediscovered within restricted coastal rocky areas on Gunner’s Quoin (Dulloo et al. 1996) and by 2003, geckos were abundant around all coastal areas of the island (Cole 2005). Additional small subpopulations were discovered on Ilot Vacoas in 1993 (0.01 km2; Arnold and Jones 1994), Pigeon House Rock in 1998 (0.01 km2; Probst and Tézier 1998), and a small isolated rocky area on Flat Island in 2003 (2.53 km2; Cole 2005, Cole et al. 2005). The Flat Island subpopulation was estimated at 61 (95% confidence interval,  range 44–85) adult geckos in 2010, but following the invasion of the island by Musk Shrews Suncus murinus in the same year, the Flat Island subpopulation became extinct in 2011 (Cole 2011). In 2011, 75 wild caught and captive-bred geckos from Ilot Vacoas were translocated to Ile Marianne (0.02 km2; MRRP 2011), where the subpopulation has now become established (MRRP unpublished data).The Lesser Night Gecko has restricted ranges on each of the four islets, occupying 0.33 km2 on Gunner’s Quoin, 0.001 km2 on Ile Marianne, 0.001 km2 on Ilot Vacoas and 0.005 km2 on Pigeon House Rock. However, using the Geospatial Conservation Assessment Tool (GeoCat) the area of occupancy is 20 km2 and the extent of occurrence is 251.2 km2. The elevation range of the species is from 0 to 125 m above sea level.
useTrade: Whilst there may be demand for the species within the pet trade, there are currently no individuals known to exist in captivity, legally or otherwise. The capture of endemic reptile in Mauritius is not permitted without the authorization of the National Parks and Conservation Service, Ministry of Agro-Industry and Food Security, Government of Mauritius.
conservationActions: The conservation of the Lesser Night Gecko is part of an ongoing conservation programme by the Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust, Mauritian Wildlife Foundation and National Parks and Conservation Service to restore the reptile communities on the offshore islets of Mauritius (Cole et al. 2009). All four islets that support Lesser Night Gecko populations are closed to public access, with Gunner’s Quoin and Ile Marianne designated as Closed Islet Nature Reserves and Ilot Vacoas and Pigeon House Rock designated as Closed Islet National Parks. The removal of rats from Gunner’s Quoin and ensuring, where possible, that the islets remain free from invasive competitors and predators has permitted the survival of the species. Whilst the loss of the Flat Island subpopulation to the invasion of the Musk Shrew in 2011 caused a decline in the extent of occurrence, the establishment of the population on Ile Marianne from the conservation introduction in 2011 led to an overall increase in the species abundance and range. Plans to translocate lesser night geckos to the Closed Nature Reserve Round Island (2.19 km2) from 2020 are underway. Round Island is a key restoration site where public access is prohibited and protected by the permanent presence of staff and wardens, jointly managed by the Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust, Mauritian Wildlife Foundation, and National Parks and Conservation Service (Jones 2008). Ongoing activities to restore the plant community on Round Island, particularly the reintroduction of native hardwoods (Jones 2008), is likely to improve habitat and food resources for the night gecko. The Mauritian Wildlife Foundation has been running educational workshops and site visits with government departments, tour operators, private boat owners and fishermen that use the southeast and northern islets to work towards reducing associated threats, which will benefit the lesser night gecko populations. The survival of this Mauritian reptile is dependent upon ongoing conservation activities, and the restoration and protection of its habitats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 294.5 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy of 156 km<sup>2</sup> (though the true area occupied within this area for this well-surveyed species is barely greater than 10 km<sup>2</sup>), it occurs as a severely fragmented population and it is undergoing a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, in the number of mature individuals, and in the number of subpopulations and area of occupancy driven by a range of threatening processes, with the major documented threats being competition from the invasive Giant Day Gecko.
habitat: The Lowland Forest Day Gecko is an arboreal habitat specialist reliant upon mature native forest, with a high species diversity that includes tall, large trees with cavities, particularly favouring Scolopia heterophylla, Foetidia mauritiana and Hilsenbergia petiolaris (Harmon et al. 2007, Bungard et al. 2014, Buckland et al. 2014b). Eighteen of the 30 subpopulations occur in small isolated patches of exotic vegetation, which predominantly consists of Eucalyptus tereticornis, Haematoxylum campechianum, Mangifera indica and/or Terminalia arjuna trees, which are generally scattered and probably act as ecological traps (Buckland et al. 2014b). In some of these 18 subpopulations, geckos persist on one or a few trees, where their long-term persistence is not viable. The 18 subpopulations are isolated from one another by urban and agricultural areas where geckos do not survive. The other 12 subpopulations that survive in pockets of native forest are surrounded by highly degraded habitat consisting of dense stands of non-native invasive guava Psidium cattleianum, where migration between subpopulations is thought to be minimal (Buckland et al. 2014c). Mature trees supply cavities, which are essential for geckos to take refuge and lay their eggs. The reproductive season is usually between July and April, with females depositing two eggs per clutch. The mean home range size of adult males is 77.0 (range: 31.6–158.3) m2 and 26.6 (range: 1.9–67.6) m2 for females (Buckland et al. 2014b).
threats: Historically, the Lowland Forest Day gecko population has declined as a result of human occupation of Mauritius from the 1500s that led to the introduction of non-native species and widespread habitat destruction. Introduced predators, such as rats (Rattus rattus), cats (Felis catus), myna birds (Acridotheres tristis), Indian house crows (Corvus splendens), red-whiskered bulbul (Pycnonotus jocosus), the agamid lizard Calotes versicolor and the Indian Wolf Snake (Lycodon aulicus) that are known predators of Mauritian Phelsuma on the mainland are thought to have contributed to declines. The Common House Gecko (Hemidactylus frenatus), which is a known competitor of the Ornate Day Gecko Phelsuma ornata (Cole 2005, Cole and Harris 2011) is also a likely competitor of the Lowland Forest Day Gecko. The Big-headed Ant (Pheidole megacephala) and Tropical Fire Ant (Solenopsis geminata) predate juvenile and adult geckos, although the extent of their impact is currently unknown (Cole 2005). The Madagascar Giant Day Gecko (Phelsuma grandis) is a recently-introduced threat that arrived in Mauritius through the pet trade in the 1990s. Research has shown that the abundance of Mauritian Phelsuma is 89% lower than expected, and in some cases the natives are completely absent, in the presence of the Madagascar Giant Day Gecko (Buckland et al. 2014a). The Madagascar Giant Day Gecko is a known predator and suspected competitor of Mauritian Phelsuma. Currently one of the extant subpopulations of the Lowland Forest Day Gecko is invaded by the Madagascar Giant Day Gecko and its predicted suitable range is likely to threaten a further 11 subpopulations (Buckland et al. 2014a). Several subpopulations of Lowland Forest Day Geckos recorded in the 1970s close to the capital Port Louis (Vinson 1976) no longer exist, in areas which have now been invaded by the Madagascar Giant Day Gecko. Given the restricted range of the lowland forest day gecko, habitat disturbance, invasive predators, extreme weather, intense cyclones and fire represent significant threats to the survival of the species.G
population: Based upon genetic research within ten of the 30 subpopulations the effective population size of each ranged between 44 and 167 (Buckland et al. 2014c). Based on the available habitat area for the other 20 subpopulations they are likely to have similar effective population sizes (Buckland et al. 2014b). The native population size is therefore considered to be below 40,000 adult geckos. Over the last 30 years documented losses of other subpopulations have occurred. Habitat continues to be lost due to urbanization, agriculture and invasion by non-native plants. There is a high risk of losing 18 of the subpopulations by the mid-2020s (Buckland et al. 2014c).
range: Once found throughout lowland areas of Mauritius (Rijsdijk et al. 2009, Buckland et al. 2014c), the Lowland Forest Day Gecko is currently restricted to 30 small and isolated sub-populations (some restricted to individual trees) from the southwest to mid-west lowlands of Mauritius (Buckland et al. 2014b). Of the 30 subpopulations, 18 are in small patches of exotic vegetation and at high risk of extinction, whilst the other 12 are in patches of high quality native forest surrounded by unsuitable invaded habitat (Buckland et al. 2014b). The area of occupancy is 156 km2, based upon grid cells, but the size of the individual subpopulations range from 0.006 to 1.0 km2 with a combined area of 10.3 km2 (Buckland et al. 2014c). The extent of occurrence is 294.5 km2. Elevation is from sea level to 420 m. Predictive modelling suggests a suitable range of 186 km2 (Buckland et al. 2014a), however, surveys within other areas where subpopulations may exist have failed to detect them. An introduced population in Oahu, Hawaii (US) was first recorded in the mid-1980s and is established in three localised suburban areas of Kailua, Kaneohe and Makiki (McKeown 1996, Lever 2003).
useTrade: Lowland Forest Day Geckos, as with all Phelsuma species, are listed in Appendix II by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) of Wild Fauna and Flora. Captive populations exist within the pet trade and there is demand for wild caught individuals, although the capture of geckos in Mauritius is not permitted without the authorization of the National Parks and Conservation Service, Ministry of Agro-Industry and Food Security, Government of Mauritius. The species is protected by the Wildlife and National Park Act 13 of 1993.
conservationActions:
The gecko occurs in lower part of Black River Gorges National Park, which is protected. Following the recommendations of Buckland et al. (2014b,c), plans are in place to harvest geckos from across as many subpopulations as possible in the next five years for captive breeding in Mauritius and at Jersey Zoo to maximise genetic variation for translocation to a protected and invasive predator-free offshore island (Round Island Management Plan 2019–2025). Habitat is currently being restored on the Closed Island Nature Reserve, Round Island (2.19 km2) with the specific goal of supporting a viable population of lowland forest day geckos. Other Nature Reserve Islands that are under restoration management, such as Gunner’s Quoin 0.70 (km2) and Ile aux Aigrettes (0.26 km2) are also considered as potential release locations.

The species is listed in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is presently common with a stable population on offshore islands, which are now likely to comprise the majority of the global population, even in areas where exotic predators are present. It has nonetheless experienced severe declines on the Mauritian mainland as a result of the introduction of the exotic giant day gecko. Should this species become established on any of this species' offshore island strongholds, it is likely to warrant immediate reassessment as at least Near Threatened.
habitat: The Ornate Day Gecko has a strong association with native dry habitat, particularly palm trees, although they will also occupy structurally diverse, non-native vegetation (Vinson 1976, Cole 2005, Harmon et al. 2007, Bungard et al. 2014). Agricultural land and areas that include monotypic stands of non-native vegetation, such as the false acacia (Leucaena leucocephala), represent poor habitat for the species, where gecko abundance is extremely low (Cole 2005, 2009; Cartwright et al. 2014). The gecko is arboreal and saxicolous and can survive in open rocky areas with crevices, cavities and boulder piles (Vinson and Vinson 1969; Cole 2005, 2009; Cole et al. 2018), which may explain its persistence in urbanized areas. The presence of tree and rock cavities and crevices is important for the presence of the species (Cole 2005, Bungard et al. 2014), as these are essential for geckos to take refuge and lay their eggs. The reproductive season is usually between July and April, with females depositing two eggs per clutch, often in communal sites. They are predominantly diurnal, although animals can also be found foraging on moonlit nights and around electric light sources (Cole 2009, Cole and Harris 2011). The total average length of adult geckos is 10 cm and they feed mostly upon invertebrates, but will also consume fruit, nectar, tree resin and small geckos, and are occasionally cannibalistic (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Nyhagen et al. 2001, Cole 2009, Cole and Harris 2011). Ornate Day Geckos are important pollinators of threatened Mauritian endemic plants (Nyhagen et al. 2001, Olesen et al. 2002, Hanson et al. 2006) and prey items of the threatened Mauritius Kestrel (Falco punctatus), Mauritius Bulbul (Hypsipetes olivaceus), Mauritius Fody (Foudia rubra), Keel-scaled Boa (Casarea dussumieri), Telfair’s Skink (Leiolopisma telfairii) and Günther’s Gecko (Phelsuma guentheri) (Cheke 1987, Jones 1987, Garrett et al. 2007, Cole et al. 2009, Zuël 2009).
threats: Introduced predators, such as cats (Felis catus), Musk Shrews (Suncus murinus), rats (Rattus rattus), Indian House Crows (Corvus splendens), myna birds (Acridotheres tristis), Red-whiskered Bulbuls (Pycnonotus jocosus), the agamid lizard Calotes versicolor, Indian Wolf Snakes (Lycodon aulicus), Madagascar Giant Day Geckos (Phelsuma grandis), Panther Chameleons (Furcifer pardalis), Big-headed Ants (Pheidole megacephala), Tropical Fire Ants (Solenopsis geminata) and Yellow Crazy Ants (Anoplolepis gracilipes) are known predators of the Ornate Day Gecko (Cole 2005, 2009, N. Cole unpublished data). The common house gecko (Hemidactylus frenatus) is a known competitor of the ornate day gecko causing a decline in abundance (Cole 2005, Cole and Harris 2011). Habitat loss, encroaching industrial areas and agriculture, extreme weather, intense cyclones and fire represent general threats. The introduction of the Madagascar giant day gecko through the pet trade in the 1990s potentially represents the greatest threat to the persistence of the ornate day gecko. Research has shown that the abundance Mauritian Phelsuma is 89% lower than expected, and in some cases the native species are completely absent, in the presence of the Madagascar Giant Day Gecko (Buckland et al. 2014). The predicted range of the Madagascar giant day gecko overlaps with the Ornate Day Gecko by 37%, but this is likely to be an underestimate as novel environments are likely to be invaded (Buckland et al. 2014). No terrestrial invasive vertebrate predators or competitors are present on two closed island nature reserves (Gunner’s Quoin with an area of 0.70 km2 and Round Island with an area of 2.19 km2) where the combine adult population size is approximately 70,000 geckos (Cole et al. 2018, N. Cole unpublished data).
population: The population size is likely to be in the hundreds of thousands, if not more. Density estimates of adult geckos obtained through line transect distance sampling on island nature reserves have been shown to vary by habitat type (Cole et al. 2018). Average (95% confidence intervals) number of adult geckos per hectare for open rocky habitats are up to 20 (3–136) geckos ha-1 , up to 59 (24–143) in rocky habitats with palms and shrubs, from 215 (195–235) to 566 (489–643)  in hardwood forests and 774 (616–973) in palm-rich habitats (Cole and Harris 2011, Cole et al. 2018). The gecko is common in lowland and coastal areas, including urban areas, but extremely scarce in agricultural land and monotypic invaded habitats (Cole 2005, 2009, Cartwright et al. 2014). Some island subpopulations appear to be stable or increasing in size as a result of habitat restoration (Cole et al. 2018). On the mainland subpopulations are in decline, particularly in areas where the introduced Madagascar Giant Day Gecko has established (Buckland et al. 2014).
range: This species is found in most coastal and lowland areas of Mauritius, except the central south coast. The species is also found on 12 offshore islands ranging in size from 0.0031 to 2.53 km<sup>2</sup> (Cole 2009). The area of occupancy has been calculated at is 988 km<sup>2 </sup>and the extent of occurrence as 2,440 km<sup>2</sup>. Elevation ranges from sea level to 520 m. The overall range of the Ornate Day Gecko throughout Mauritius has remained largely unchanged since surveys in the 1960s and 1970s (Vinson 1976).
useTrade: Ornate Day Geckos, as with all Phelsuma species, are listed in Appendix II by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) of Wild Fauna and Flora. Captive populations exist within the pet trade and there is some demand for wild caught individuals, although the capture of geckos in Mauritius is not permitted without the authorisation of the National Parks and Conservation Service, Ministry of Agro-Industry and Food Security, Government of Mauritius. The species breeds well in captivity and there is no organised trade from Mauritius.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measure for the species, but it benefits from habitat restoration on four islands within its range and at least four locations on the mainland. It is found in eight protected areas, which include the lower part of the Black River Gorges National Park, Bras d’Eau National Park, Ile d’Ambre National Park and the Nature Reserves: Ile aux Aigrettes, Gunner’s Quoin, Flat Island, Gabriel Island and Round Island. On Iles aux Aigrettes, Gabriella Island and Flat Island. No other conservation actions are needed at present, although monitoring and biosecurity measures need to be maintained to ensure that the Madagascar Giant Day Gecko does not become established on the islands.

rationale: Chamaeleo senegalensis is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and abundance. While its population may be deleteriously impacted by exploitation, there is currently no indication that any population declines are severe enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category. However, monitoring and research is needed for this species to ensure that significant population declines are prevented in future.
habitat: This species inhabits dry forest and dry Sudanese and Sudanese-Sahelian savanna (Trape et al. 2012). It ranges into Guinean moist savanna, but is less common in this habitat than C. gracilis, the typical chameleon of humid West African savanna (Trape et al. 2012). Reports of this species from humid lowland forest (Leaché 2006, Gonwou 2002, Schmidt 1919) are likely to be incorrect and to refer to C. gracilis (M-O. Rödel pers. comm. 2012). It can be abundant in both towns and villages, where this arboreal lizard favours introduced Neem trees along roads and paths (Trape et al. 2012). It is diurnal and feeds on insects and other arthropods (Trape et al. 2012).
threats: This species is of value to the pet trade industry (UNEP-WCMC 2010) and is also used as medicine and sold in alternative markets (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). To date, there are no known or observed effects of harvesting on natural populations. Although completely harmless, chameleons are much feared by local people in parts of West Africa (Trape et al. 2012), and there may therefore be some degree of persecution.
population: This species is reported to be common in the Western African humid savannas, especially in northern Côte d'Ivoire (M-O. Rödel pers. comm. 2012) and Togo (G. Segniagbeto pers. comm. 2012). It is, however, very much rarer in humid savanna than C. gracilis (Trape et al. 2012). It is often abundant in towns and villages, particularly in introduced Neem trees (Azadirachta indica A.Juss.) (Trape et al. 2012).
range: This species is very widely distributed in the savannas and dry forests of West Africa, ranging from Senegal to Nigeria (Trape et al. 2012). Records from further east, including Cameroon and Chad, are attributable to C. laevigatus, formerly a subspecies of this form. Records also exist for the Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Mali, Cote d'Ivôire, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Togo and Benin (Trape et al. 2012), as well as southwestern Niger. It ranges from sea level to 1,900 m asl.
useTrade: Approximately 170,000 live individuals were reportedly exported between 2000 and 2009 (UNEP-WCMC 2010) mainly for the pet trade. The exports came predominantly from Togo, Benin and Ghana, with around 160,000 exported from these countries during this period (UNEP-WCMC 2010). The species is also sold for medicine (M.-O. Rödel and G. Segniagbeto pers. comms. 2012).
conservationActions: This species is listed on CITES Appendix II. In places its distribution coincides with protected areas. Further research on harvest levels and monitoring of population trends are needed.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,003 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, it is considered to occur in five threat-defined locations, and the quality and extent of its montane forest habitat in the Usambara and Nguu Mountains is declining.
habitat: It is found in lowland and montane forest, and has also been found in moderately disturbed habitats in the East Usambaras (S. Loader and J. Vonesh pers. comm June 2012). It does not occur in heavily disturbed forest or in open areas. However, it is locally abundant in stands of introduced bamboo in the Amani Botanic Garden. It is sometimes associated with wild bananas (Barbour and Loveridge 1928). The eggs are deposited in hollow bamboo stems or leaf axils and tree holes where water is trapped, and where the larvae develop (Harper et al. 2010).
threats: It is almost certainly adversely affected by ongoing forest loss and degradation, especially from encroaching small-scale agriculture. The area was historically impacted by intensive small-scale artisanal  gold mining; however, it is unlikely that this species was severely impacted given  that it is not stream-dependent (J. Vonesh and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
population: It is generally an uncommon species, and is very hard to find outside the breeding season. However, it is easily found in the Amani Botanic Garden in the East Usambaras during the breeding season due to the extensive stands of exotic bamboo, with which it is closely associated. Its population is considered to be severely fragmented (S. Loader and J. Vonesh pers. comm. June 2012).
range: This species is known with certainty from the East and West Usambara Mountains and the Nguu Mountains in north-eastern Tanzania. Its elevational ranges varies from 180 m to at least 1,200 m asl. Taking range as a proxy for extent of occurrence (EOO), this is estimated to be ca 1,003 km2. Its range is not likely to increase much more, and it is currently estimated to occur in five threat-defined locations, which are likely to decrease in number once taxonomy of this complex is resolved (S. Loader and J. Vonesh pers. comm. June 2012).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs in the Amani and Nilo Nature Reserves, and in several forest reserves in East and West Usambaras and in Nguu Mountain (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012); although these reserves are relatively well protected in comparison to other protected areas in the region, there is still a need for increased protection and improved management (S. Loader and J. Vonesh pers. comm. June 2012). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and natural history, as well as clarification on its taxonomic identity.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an area of occupancy which will not much exceed 250 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two locations (Réunion, where the most widespread threat is from invasive species; and the Agalela islands where specific threats are unknown), and it is subject to ongoing declines in the extent and quality of its habitat in Réunion, the largest part of its range, as a result of various pressures but particularly the spread of invasive plants.
habitat:
This gecko is predominantly arboreal and diurnal, and is mainly associated with native forest. In coastal areas it occurs in remnant native vegetation, including Pandanus thickets. It also inhabits semi-dry tropical forests (west coast 200–750 m asl), low and medium altitude humid tropical forests (west coast 750–1000 m; east coast 0-900 m asl), and in the lower part of tropical moist montane forests (1,000–1,200 m asl). Above 1,500 m, it only inhabits specific areas well-exposed to the sun, such as streambeds, steep vegetated cliffs, cliffs and rocky ridges. Two high-elevation subpopulations (> 2,000 m asl) are known, in which geckos exhibit saxicolous behaviour, living in cliffs and/or rocky ridges (Sanchez and Probst 2017a). On the Agalela islands it occurs on coconut palms, dead casuarina trees, on banana palms and in buildings, and occurs in vegetated areas down to the strandline (Cheke 1975, Webster and Cardinouche 2013). The availability of egg laying sites (e.g. trunk and rock crevices, cavities), also used as retreat sites, could be a factor limiting populations dynamics of this gecko, but this remains to be tested experimentally (Sanchez and Probst, 2017b). The availability of thermoregulation sites could also be a significant limiting factor (Augros et al. 2017).

A study of reproduction conducted in one subpopulation located on the east coast of Réunion  (800 m asl) reveals that the reproductive season is usually between June to January, with females depositing one or two eggs per clutch, which take a maximum of approximately 140–195 days to incubate. Reunion Day Gecko glue their eggs to the substrate. Approximately 90% of eggs that are deposited on Pandanus trunks hatch. In artificial eggs-laying sites, hatching rates ranged from 54% to 92% on metal supports (metal tubes and poles), and are evaluated at 90% on wooden supports (kiosks, information boards, etc.) (Sanchez and Gérard 2017). In captivity, geckos reach maturity within two years, and it could be similar in natural condition (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). The gecko’s diet includes insects, fruit pulp and nectar. The Reunion Day Gecko is probably a pollinator of several native plant species (Sanchez and Probst 2017b).
threats: Eggs scars, bone deposits and historical testimonies all suggest that this species was more widespread on Réunion at least until shortly after human colonization in the 17th century. It is likely that a large population decline has taken place since, probably due to habitat modification and predation pressures by introduced alien animals. The expansion of sugarcane plantations on both the west and east coasts, have probably destroyed a large part of the former distribution area. Although much of this land clearance is historical, ongoing habitat modification and increasingly dense urbanization remain threats to this species on Réunion. Remaining natural habitats are under pressure from both deliberate and accidental fire, but the primary threat to this species in natural habitats is invasive plants, which close suitable open habitats and increase homogenization of the vegetation communities, as well as increasing the susceptibility of these habitats to fire, although the species can maintain subpopulations in certain invasive plant formations at relatively low levels of invasion (Sanchez and Probst 2017a,b). High-elevation subpopulations are at risk from illegal fires, which are followed by plant invasion. Subpopulations at lower elevations are threatened by clearing for cultivation and urbanization (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). Other threats include predation by and competition with several introduced mammals, reptiles and birds. Black Rats eat geckos’ eggs laid inside tree trunks (Sanchez and Gérard 2017) and Wolf Snakes (Lycodon aulicus) consume adult geckos. Predation by several other invasive species of mammals and birds, and the invasive Giant Day Gecko Phelsuma grandis, is suspected (Sanchez and Caceres 2019), although sympatry between the latter species and P. borbonica has not yet been confirmed (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019).. Competition with invasive day geckos (Phelsuma laticauda and P. grandis) could become a major threat in future (Buckland et al. 2014, Sanchez and Probst 2014). Levels of exploitation for the global pet trade are unknown, and are not thought to represent a threat to this species, but some poaching of wild animals is likely to be ongoing. Nothing is known of any threats on the Agalela islands; based on satellite imagery these islands are heavily developed and cultivated with native vegetation surviving only on slopes, but the species appears to be common on exotic palms and around buildings on these islands.
population: This species was described as being "numerous" on both Agalega islands (Webster and Cardinouche 2013), but population trends here are unknown. Based on the number of geckos observed in each coconut palm tree and the number of coconut palms on islands (in the order of 400,000), Cheke (1975) gave an estimation of the population size run into several hundred thousand. Where the species survives on Réunion it can be locally common in well-preserved humid forest but is thought to have become rarer since human settlement, because of land conversion for agriculture, native habitats replacement by invasive vegetation and introduction of invasive animals, including invasive reptiles. Subpopulations in the west, centre and north of the island exhibit a high degree of fragmentation, while those in the east and south exhibit a more continuous distribution. Based on several transect counts, the size of the high-elevation subpopulation of Maïdo (2,200–2,350 m asl) has been estimated between 200 and 600 geckos (Probst and Abhaya 2004). In 2018, 50 geckos were translocated by the National Park, from Plaine Affouches (650–1,000 m asl) to Cap Francis (500 m asl), in the north of the island (Sanchez et al. 2016, Sanchez 2018). Prior to translocation a feasibility study was carried out in 2017 on the source population, which found that it contained several hundred of mature geckos, and that the species was more abundant in native than disturbed vegetation (Bonanno 2016). Additionally, the observed sex ratio differed between habitats, being 50:50 in native vegetation but male-biased in disturbed habitat (Bonanno et al. 2017).
range: This gecko inhabits Réunion, where it is found mainly in the north, east, southeast and south of the island (but with some subpopulations in the west and centre), and both of the Agalega islands (part of Mauritius, and about 1,000 km north of the main island). It has an estimated extent of occurrence of 42,000 km<sup>2</sup>, although this is strongly inflated by the wide separation between the two island groups. On Réunion it has an area of occupancy of around 250 km<sup>2</sup> based on 2x2 km grid cells; its area of occupancy on the Agalega islands is unknown, but the islands have a combined area of 2,600 ha. It occurs between sea level and 2,800 m asl, but not continuously along an elevational gradient: there are subpopulations on Réunion both on the coast and elevations above 2,000 m asl. The distribution on Réunion is likely to be relictual, as subfossils (eggs and bones) suggest that before human settlement (and associated mammal invasions) in the 17th century the gecko may have been present throughout the island (Sanchez and Probst 2017a).
useTrade: This is a very colourful gecko, and there is some trade in this species within Europe and the US. It is likely that some animals are collected from the wild presumably from Réunion (any exploitation of the Agalela subspecies is unknown) to support this activity, but there is no way to quantify harvest levels (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
A National Recovery Plan has been proposed to restore subpopulations of this species (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). Artificial egg laying site/shelter devices (AELS) have been tested to assist in the recolonization of a site destroyed by the construction of a water storage tank, but monitoring (2010–2014) demonstrated a very low recolonization of the area (<4%) after the works, mainly as a result of a lack of wooded vegetation on the site. Geckos used 25% of the AELS for reproduction, mostly those located at the edge of the native forest, with at least 400 eggs laid during the monitoring period (Sanchez 2012, 2014). Preliminary results have shown that rats do not detect the eggs when they are deposited in these artificial devices hatch, but further research is needed to clarify whether these are effective at restoring natural subpopulations (Sanchez and Vingadachetty 2016, Sanchez and Gérard 2017).

As part of a European nature conservation project led by the National Park (LIFE +Forêt Sèche), aimed at preserving the semi-dry tropical forests a reintroduction has been conducted in 2018, notably with the aim of restoring the role of the gecko as a plant pollinator in this threatened habitat. Geckos were translocated from Plaine Affouches (650–1,000 m asl) to Cap Francis (500 m asl), located in the north of the island (Sanchez et al. 2016, Sanchez 2018). The release site was previously restored and rats were controlled since December 2017. The released subpopulation is monitored by the National Park using several methods (e.g, foot print, AELS control, visual search/baiting, photo-identification and photographic traps) (Couturier et al. 2019, Piteau et al. 2019). During the monitoring period (April 2018– April 2019), 11 different geckos were detected. One year after release, the probability of apparent survival (being alive and still at the site to release) is 0.02 [95% CI: 0.0002–0.10] and the probable number of remaining geckos on the site would therefore be estimated at 1 [95% CI: 0–5], a rate too low for the establishment of a viable population (Couturier et al. 2019).

Due to high level of genetic differentiation between subpopulations in Réunion Island (Thébaud 2013), more research is needed into the taxonomic status of this species. Conservation strategy must consider genetically and geographically isolated subpopulations, which should be closely monitored and managed in case future threats arise (Sanchez and Caceres 2019).

The species is listed in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 15 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and it is subject to an observed continuing decline in the extent and quality of suitable habitat, the number of mature individuals, the number of subpopulations and a likely continuing decline in the area of occupancy.
habitat:
This arboreal gecko is strongly associated with palms and palm-like trees. In coastal remnant vegetation it occurs in Pandanus thickets. It can also survive in invasive Furcraea foetida thickets in open areas. In gardens and urban areas it also occurs on planted Pandanus and ornamental exotic plants (including species of Ravenala, Dypsis and Latania) (Sanchez and Caceres 2011). The diet includes insects, fruit pulp, nectar and pollen. The Manapany Day Gecko is probably a pollinator of several native plant species (Sanchez et al. 2009, Clémencet et al. 2013).

Captive geckos reach sexual maturity within two years, and this is likely to be similar in nature (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). Reproduction may take place throughout the year, but in two subpopulations subject to ongoing monitoring females seem to lay only one or two clutches of two eggs a year, laid in September with eggs taking 62–104 days to hatch. Survival rates of juveniles are probably low, particularly during the first year (Sanchez and Choeur 2019, A. Choeur and M. Sanchez unpubl. data).
threats: Subfossil egg remains and historical testimonies are suggestive of a large population decline since human settlement, probably due to habitat modification and predation pressures from invasive animals. Habitat modification of native coastal vegetation, much of which has been lost, and urban expansion and intensification are threats to the surviving population. Remaining coastal vegetation is subject to degradation and replacement by invasive plants, and recruitment of new plants is low as a result of seed predation by rats (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019). As a result, the area of remaining suitable coastal vegetation is in slow decline even in the absence of direct land conversion (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019). These pressure contribute to population fragmentation. Other threats to the gecko included predation and competition by invasive mammals, reptiles and birds. Invasive Wolf Snakes (Lycodon aulicus) eat adult geckos. Predation is suspected or confirmed for several other invasive species (birds: Pycnonotus jocosus, Acridotheres tristis; mammals: Mus musculus, Rattus rattus, Suncus murinus; day geckos Phelsuma grandis; ants Solenopsis geminata) (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). Competition with invasive day geckos (Phelsuma laticauda and P. grandis) could become a major threat in the near future (Buckland et al. 2014). Levels of exploitation for the international pet trade are unknown, and unlikely to represent a major threat, but some collection of wild animals may be ongoing. This species could be strongly affected by climate change over the long term: projections for the end of the century suggest a rise in temperatures between 1.7 and 2.6 °C and an overall decrease in rainfall over the southwestern parts of the island in winter, encompassing the range of this gecko. The rise of temperatures and a strong dry season could respectively affect the population's sex-ratio and availability of food resources, and consequently increasing extinction risk (Sanchez and Caceres 2019).
population:
This species is rare, which is presumed to be a consequence of historical land conversion for agriculture, replacement of native with invasive vegetation and the introduction of invasive animals. Bour et al. (1995) estimated the global population to be between 5,000 and 10,000 individuals, based on estimates derived from counts in multiple subpopulations. A subsequent intensive field study reported by Sanchez and Prost (2011) produced an estimate of 3,000–5,000 individuals, corresponding to 2,000 to 3,300 mature individuals based on observed ratios of juveniles to adults. These authors attempted to replicate the 1995 survey's methodology using transect surveys of the same localities, and estimated trends within each subpopulation based on these results, but Bour et al. (1995) did not report the amount of survey effort and the degree to which the results are comparable is consequently unclear (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019).

According to data collected over the last ten years (2008–2018), 52 fragmented subpopulations have been identified, within which, at least one is introduced. The status of many subpopulations is currently uncertain and several are probably extinct (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019). Manapany-les-Bains represents the largest population, in both size and area occupied; M. Sanchez (pers. comm. 2019) estimates that this contains 400–800 mature individuals, and fragmentation within this subpopulation has been observed as a result of roads, unsuitable areas of disturbed vegetation, and urban areas without suitable gardens. Monitoring of two subpopulations 60 m apart using photo-identification in natural cliff habitat subject to habitat management has been ongoing since 2015 (Sanchez and Choeur unpubl. data). These found that there is no exchange of adults between these subpopulations, which are separated by invasive shrubs, suggesting very low mobility (estimated below 40 m) in non-suitable vegetation. Adult recruitment between 2016 and 2018 was found to decrease in monitored subpopulations, hypothesized to be a consequence of low annual survival of juveniles (estimated at below 30%) and females (estimated at 52–66%) in both subpopulations during this period, compared with 74% for adult males. Between 2016 and 2018 mature population size at these localities declined by 44 and 38%. Modelling in VORTEX suggests that these subpopulations have a greater than 30% chance to become extinct within 15 years. The global population is considered to be severely fragmented.
range: This species is endemic to Réunion, but its original natural distribution on this island is unclear due to the long history of human disturbance and its presumed extinction from much of its original range. It presently has a fragmentary and highly restricted distribution in the south, mostly within 100 m of the coast where it occurs in vegetation on coastal cliffs, but based on the known ecology of its Mauritian sister species Phelsuma ornata it may once have occurred throughout the west coast where semi-xerophilic vegetation historically occurred. Fossil bones and eggs of Phelsuma from elsewhere on Réunion's west coast may support this hypothesis, but have not been specifically identified. It is however possible that its distribution was always confined to the south of the island, perhaps as a result of competition with Phelsuma borbonica (Sanchez et al. 2009). Within the current distribution, there is some confusion surrounding which of the known subpopulations are native and which introduced as the species can persist in private gardens and at least one subpopulation is known to be introduced. Some, notably those in the township of Petite Ile and Saint Joseph, these may represent remnant subpopulations or unintentional reintroductions within the species' native range (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019). Overall the distribution is probably contracting, as a number of subpopulations were found to be close to extinction between 2008 and 2010 (Sanchez and Probst 2011) and many are likely to be extinct (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019). Within its presumed natural range it reaches elevations as high as 200 m asl (Sanchez and Probst 2011).
useTrade: There is some trade in Réunion day geckos, including Phelsuma inexpectata, within Europe and US. It is likely that some animals are collected from the wild to support this activity (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
The Manapany Day Gecko benefits from a national recovery plan (Sanchez and Caceres 2019), and is part of a current conservation programme by the Nature Océan Indien NGO. Since 2012, restoration of native vegetation has been ongoing in two gecko subpopulations in native cliff habitats and monitoring of these subpopulations has been ongoing since 2015. Invasive shrub vegetation is gradually being replaced by native palm species. These populations have annually monitored since 2015 and evidence so far suggests that they are declining towards extinction despite management. The lack of monitoring of control subpopulations in areas not subject to management makes it impossible to determine whether these management actions have benefitted this species.

Predator control programme must be urgently carried out in an effort to slow observed rates of decline.

Since 2013 an NGO drive, called the “gardens and geckos” initiative, has promoted the conservation of subpopulations located in private, garden and urbanized environments. This participatory approach involves 150 inhabitants who committed to keep suitable vegetation in the gardens, avoid destruction of geckos and eggs, and avoid the use of chemical pesticides. Approximately 50% of the area occupied by the gecko in urban areas is now managed this way (Sanchez and Caceres 2019).
In Manapany-les-Bains village, control of invasive populations of Phelsuma laticauda has been underway since 2018, and expansion of this and another invasive day gecko, P. grandis, are tracked as these species may represent a significant threat (Buckland et al. 2014, Lund 2016, Sanchez and Probst 2016). Research is needed to investigate the effects of threatening processes on this gecko, including this invasive species, and into the structure and genetic diversity within subpopulations. As the most recent population data available for this gecko dates to 2011, a re-evaluation of the species' distribution and the sizes of surviving subpopulations is urgently required (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2019).

The species is listed in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is confined to an island with an area below 1,000 km<sup>2</sup>, it is widespread and abundant in the modified habitats that cover most of Pemba, and is not thought to be subject to any ongoing threats.
habitat: This species is diurnal, and arboreal on a variety of trees, primarily on coconut (Spawls et al. 2002, Rödder et al. 2010), but also on true palms and jacktree, as well as on banana plants (Rödder et al. 2010), in both coastal areas and plantations. It appears only to avoid the island's drier savanna and woodland habitats, clove plantations, and mangroves, and few individuals have been found in forest (Rödder et al. 2010). Animals have been recorded from 1.5 to 12 m above ground (Rödder et al. 2010), and appear to be most active in the afternoon between 15:00 and 18:00 (Rödder et al. 2010).
threats: This species appears highly tolerant of anthropogenic disturbance, and from its rarity in natural forest it appears that it may have benefited from the expansion of plantations across much of Pemba (Rödder et al. 2010). It may be at some risk if unsuitable anthropogenic habitats, such as clove plantations and rice paddies expand, or if use of pesticides increases, but there is currently no indication that this is likely (Rödder et al. 2010). The introduction of Phelsuma dubia, which is ecologically similar to P. parkeri and is found on the nearby island of Zanzibar, is plausible due to regular boat traffic between these islands (Spawls et al. 2002), and may be a possible future threat (Rödder et al. 2010). The likely impact of this species on P. parkeri, should it become established on Pemba is, however, unknown (Rödder et al. 2010). Pemba has one of the wettest climates in East Africa and may be affected by climate change in the long term, but P. parkeri is thought likely to be able to adapt to at least moderate climate impacts (Rödder et al. 2010). Recent export levels for the international pet trade are thought likely to be sustainable (Rödder et al. 2010), and demand is currently limited or nonexistent.
population: This species is considered to be widespread and abundant, being found in most habitats on Pemba with suitable trees, and at its most abundant in coconut and banana plantations (Rödder et al. 2010). It is, however, shy and difficult to spot (Rödder et al. 2010). These authors infer from the occurrence of geckos on seemingly suboptimal small banana plants and palms that all suitable trees may be colonized in areas where the gecko occurs; if this is the case, the gecko will be "extremely abundant" across much of Pemba (Rödder et al. 2010).
range: This species is endemic to Pemba Island, off the coast of Tanzania (Spawls et al. 2002). It is known from sites in both the north and south of the island (Spawls et al. 2002), and recent surveys recorded the species from 39 localities (Rödder et al. 2010). It is possible that it occurs on Zanzibar but has been overlooked due to the presence of the Zanzibar Day Gecko Phelsuma dubia; alternatively as boat traffic between the two islands is common, it might be introduced to Zanzibar in future (Spawls et al. 2002). Pemba has a maximum elevation of less than 100 m asl. (Rödder et al. 2010).
useTrade: This species has recently become available in the international pet trade, and is rarely bred in captivity (Rödder et al. 2010). An annual export quota of 1,000 individuals a year has been set, and is considered likely to be sustainable if maintained at this level (Rödder et al. 2010). Since 2011 trade appears to have ceased, as there is no demand in America or Europe for this gecko (J. Beraducci pers. comm. 2014)
conservationActions: All Phelsuma species are included on CITES Appendix II, and in 2008 an export quota of 1,000 P. parkeri individuals a year was imposed (Rödder et al. 2010). Population monitoring is recommended to provide warning of any changes in population status should the potential competitor P. dubia become established on Pemba (Rödder et al. 2010).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population in the Highlands of Tanzania.
habitat: It lives on the ground in leaf-litter, stony ground, bare ground and paths in submontane and montane forests, cultivated land, marshland, plantations, introduced bamboo and grassland. It is very tolerant to many different habitats. It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water.
threats: In view of its tolerance to different habitats, it is probably not facing any significant threats.
population: It is a very common species.
range: This species is known from the following mountain ranges in northeastern, eastern and southern Tanzania: North Pare, South Pare, West Usambara, East Usambara, Nguu, Nguru, Uluguru, Rubeho, Udzungwa (south at least to the Kihansi Gorge), and Mount Rungwe. It possibly occurs in some of the coastal forests of Tanzania, but this requires confirmation. It is a montane species and has been recorded at 850-2,050 m asl, with possibly a wider elevational range (Poynton 2003).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs in the Udzungwa National Park and the Amani Nature Reserve. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the identity of this taxon.

rationale: Anolis grahami is listed as Least Concern in view of its tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be undergoing significant declines to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species is often found in trees, bushes, fence posts, brush heaps, and on large rocks in a variety of habitats, including open mesic forest (although rarely in dense forest), grazed pastures, well-watered shady gardens, xeric coastal growth, xeric forest, and on the walls of buildings (Schwartz and Henderson 1991, Henderson and Powell 2009). The species will hunt insects at night around lights on buildings (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2017). It is an oviparous species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: No threats seem to be causing overall population reductions to the species at this time (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015).
population: This is one of the most common and widespread anoles on Jamaica, with no evidence of any population decline (Crombie 1999).
range: This species is endemic to Jamaica, and was deliberately introduced to Bermuda in 1905 as an intended biocontrol agent (Wingate 1965, Henderson and Powell 2009). On Jamaica, it is relatively widespread across the island and occurs from sea level to ~1,000 m (Wilson and Vogel 2000, Henderson and Powell 2009, B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015). In the invaded range, the species presently occurs throughout the Bermuda archipelago (Henderson and Powell 2009, Macedonia et al. 2016). Despite occasional rumours, Anolis grahami has not been recorded from Florida, USA (J. Stroud pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: The species does occur in the pet trade (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015).
conservationActions: Specific conservation actions are not presently needed for this species,  as it is able to thrive in small-scale diversified agricultural plots,  as well as in natural forest habitats. This species occurs in a number  of protected areas, although some of these areas nonetheless experience  substantial illicit habitat degradation (B. Wilson, pers. comm. 2015). Of note, significant geographic variation in phenotype exists (J. Burgess pers. comm. 2018) and two subspecies are recognized (Henderson and Powell 2009); which might correspond to cryptic species boundaries and thus impact conservation action.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (with an extent of occurrence of only of 467 km<sup>2</sup>), it is locally abundant, the population trend is stable, there are no current threats, and it adapts to human altered habitats.
habitat: This species is found on a wide variety of vertical substrates within its known range in both natural and anthropogenic habitats, including tree trunks, buildings, light posts, etc. (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015).
threats: No major threats are known. This species is tolerant of substantial habitat disturbance.
population: This species is abundant. The population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is endemic to Haiti along the southeastern coast of the Tiburon Peninsula. The elevational range is 0-182 m (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Anolis valencienni is listed as Least Concern in view of its distribution across the whole of Jamaica, its occurrence in a broad range of habitats, and its apparent tolerance of moderate anthropogenic habitat disturbance. Furthermore, its distribution coincides with several protected areas.
habitat: This species inhabits forest and woodlands, secondary growth forest, and has also been found in residential areas, such as orchards in suburban areas (Schwartz and Henderson 1991, K. de Queiroz pers. comm. 2010, D.L. Mahler pers. comm. 2018).
threats: No threats seem to be causing overall population reductions to the species at this time (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015, D.L. Mahler pers. comm. 2018).
population: This slow-moving species can be hard to detect, and is less abundant than most other Jamaican anoles, but does not show evidence of decline in any parts of its range (D.L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015). In mark-resample studies conducted in June through August, 2018, Anolis valencienni was estimated to exhibit similar densities in natural and highly disturbed dry forest habitats in southern Jamaica (L.O. Frishkoff and D.L. Mahler 2018, unpublished).
range: This species is endemic to Jamaica. The species has an elevation range between 0 and 1,220 m above sea level (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: The species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: Specific conservation actions are not presently needed for this species, as it is able to thrive in small-scale diversified agricultural plots, as well as in natural forest habitats. This species occurs in a number of protected areas, although some of these areas nonetheless experience substantial illicit habitat degradation (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015).

rationale: The species is inferred to have undergone population size reduction of >30% over the last decade based on the fact that reported incidence of exploitation has increased by at least one-and-a-half times, as as result of new demand for consumption generated by recent Chinese immigrant populations. Loss of forest cover has also contributed to population declines (Newman et al. 2016). The generation length is assumed to be 3–4 years. Only 20 areas of occurrence are currently known on the island, half of which are smaller than 20 km2 (Newman et al. 2016).
habitat: A nocturnal snake found in forested habitats and plantations, observed in rock crevices, caves, and trees (Henderson and Powell 2009). It feeds on lizards, birds, and bats (Lynn and Grant 1940, Henderson and Powell 2009); as well as introduced rodents (Lynn and Grant 1940, B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015) and Rhinella marina (Wilson et al. 2011).
threats: The most severe threats to the species are habitat loss and direct human persecution, including local traditions of killing large snakes on sight. Recent Chinese immigration has reportedly stimulated a market demand for boas, and the species is also harvested for local and international pet trade (Wilson et al. 2011). Other threats to the species include forest loss owing to bauxite mining, charcoal production, and urbanization (Tole 2006, Newman et al. 2016). Bauxite mining is a particular threat for populations in Cockpit Country (Tzika et al. 2008, Newman et al. 2011). The species is also negatively impacted by invasive species, as juveniles are eaten by introduced mongoose, and boas suffer mortality from bufotoxin poisoning following ingestion of introduced Rhinella marina (Wilson et al. 2011). Lynn and Grant (1940) note that populations were reduced in the early 20th century by depredation by mongoose and feral cats. A captive breeding programme of the species was established by the Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust in Jersey (cf. Tzika et al. 2009).
population: The species' population size is inferred to have declined by >30% over the last decade (with presumed wide geographic variation in the exact percentage), based on the fact that reported exploitation has - very approximately - increased one-and-a-half times over this period. Given ongoing immigration (and concomitant increasing demand for boas) associated with infrastructure development projects, these declines are projected to intensify into the future, but the exact rate cannot yet be inferred. The exact generation length of the species is unknown: certainly between one and ten years.
range: This species is endemic to Jamaica where is was once widespread across the island (Gosse 1851). It occurs from sea level to mid-elevations (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015) and is mostly found in undisturbed intact forests, though he species will use secondary forests and open woodlands (Newman et al. 2016). The species has experienced significant range contraction and is presently restricted to isolated areas on Jamaica; and populations are highly fragmented (Newman et al. 2016). It has been extirpated from Great Goat Island (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015) where it previously occurred (Lynn and Grant 1940).
useTrade: The species is harvested for local and international pet trade (Wilson et al. 2011), and recent Chinese immigration into Jamaica has reportedly stimulated a market demand for boas for consumption. During the period 2000–18 shipments were only documented until 2013; reporting the export of 115 live specimens, with the major exporter being Jersey (and so implying that these were derived from the captive population). Jamaica exported 69 specimens for scientific purposes to Belgium and the USA (https://trade.cites.org).
conservationActions: The species is listed in CITES Appendix I, and on the list of animals specially protected under the Jamaican Wild Life Protection Act (Wild Life Protection Act 1945, Wilson et al. 2011). It is also listed as a Foreign Endangered Species on the United State Endangered Species List (USFWS 1970). The Windsor Research Centre in The Cockpit Country and the Sevenoaks Nature Sanctuary in St. Anne Parish run a public education campaign to increase awareness of the species (Wilson et al. 2011). The species is maintained in ex situ captive collections at the Jersey Zoo and elsewhere, and is bred in private collections in the US, Canada, and Europe (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2018). The highest priority conservation measure is enforcement of the Wild Life Protection Act to curtail the illegal harvest and persecution of the species. Others actions should include public education and awareness focusing on the beneficial role of boas (consuming rats carrying leptospirosis), and communicating in both English and Chinese that boa harvest is illegal; reintroduction into the Goat Islands; and research into the impacts of the increasing consumption of the species. Protection of existing primary forests, particularly in Cockpit Country, would also greatly benefit the species (Newman et al. 2016). A translocation program was established as a conservation strategy (see Newman et al. 2019).

rationale: Known from only six sites which probably represent a single location, a restricted distributional range estimated at 1,327 km2 and the area of occupancy is estimated at 96 km2 from six known locations (using a 16 km2 grid area). The main threat to this fossorial species is the continuous decline in the quality and extent of its preferred natural habitats within low-lying and high-altitude indigenous Afromontane forests in the Grootbos-Magoebaskloof area (Northern Mistbelt Forests, Envirotek 2003; Wolkberg Afromontane Forest Belt, IBA_SA SA005) and adjoining montane grasslands. Commercial forestry operations and associated road infrastructure cause severe degradation and fragmentation of natural forests, and only small fragments of its habitat are protected in state-controlled forest reserves. However, protection measures on the ground are dubious and do not target management of this species. Increasing privatization of some state forests brings the continued protection of this species’ habitat into doubt. Agriculture, rural and urban housing and tourism infrastructure development around Haenertsburg are additional but more localized causes of habitat destruction, fragmentation and loss. Therefore the species is listed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii).
habitat: Occurs in moist sandy loam soils along watercourses in low and high altitude moist Afromontane forests (Northern Mistbelt Forests, Envirotek 2003) and surrounding Northeastern Mountain Grassland of Limpopo Province (Savanna biome). Also occurs in pastoral and cultivated lands (livestock and tea farming) and young pine plantations, where it coexists with Common Mole-rats (Cryptomys hottentotus). It thrives in rural and urban gardens and uses stretches of suitable soil on road edges as movement corridors. Nocturnal foraging takes place in shallow subsurface tunnels; with increased activity after rain. Adults are solitary, except mothers with young. Little is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: In the former Transvaal Province (South Africa), a large geopolitical area now comprising the Gauteng, Limpopo, North-West and Mpumalanga provinces, this species was given the highest regional priority score for mammals (Freitag and van Jaarsveld 1997). Within its extent of occurrence, the distribution of populations is highly localized and naturally fragmented due to a preference for soft sandy loam soils along watercourses, especially in indigenous forests. Inferred major threats are severe habitat alteration and fragmentation of Afromontane forest and adjoining grasslands by commercial forestry operations and associated roads infrastructure. Although somewhat limited, expanding rural and urban housing, commercial and tourism infrastructure developments in the last five years have resulted in areas of suitable habitat being cleared or severely transformed. Minor threats include overgrazing of pastoral land along watercourses, predation by pets and persecution by gardeners in rural and urban settlements.
population: Very localized population, but locally common; most numerous in moist sandy loam soils associated with high altitude riverine forests near watercourses and ponds.
range: Recorded only from six localities in the Grootbos-Magoebaskloof area (Woodbush-De Hoek) of the far Northern Eastern Escarpment (Drakensberg) between Haenertsburg, New Agatha and Tzaneen in Limpopo Province (South Africa). Three of the six confirmed localities fall within protected indigenous forest reserves (De Hoek, Woodbush and New Agatha). All of these records fall within the southern section of the Northern Mistbelt Forests (Envirotek 2003)/ Wolkberg Afromontane Forest Belt (IBA_SA – SA005).
conservationActions: Protected in the De Hoek, New Agatha and Woodbush Forest Reserves. Research needed to document most aspects of natural history, ecology, evolutionary relationships, phylogeography and population genetics of this species.
