population: This species has been reported as common in its habitat in Belize and Costa Rica (Stafford and Meyer 2000, Savage 2002). In Honduras, some subpopulations of this species are severely depleted (Puerto Lempira, Gracias a Dios), whereas it remains abundant along the entire Pacific versant in Valle and Choluteca (J. McCranie pers. comm. 2009).
range: This species can be found from the Isthmus of Tehuantepec southwards through Central America. It occurs on both the Caribbean and Pacific versants and on several offshore islands, including: Cozumel, Mujeres, and del Carmen, Mexico (de Queiroz 1995, Köhler and Streit 1996); Utila and Guanaja, Honduras; Maiz Grande and Maiz Pequeno, Nicaragua (S. Pasachnik pers. obs. 2008); El Rey, Panama; and Providencia and San Andres, Columbia (de Queiroz 1995). It has also been introduced to Florida, USA, and has now established a reproducing population (Enge 2006).  A recent report also indicates that this species has been introduced into Venezuela, near Lecharias, along the road from Barcelona to La Cruz (Barrio-Amoros and Rivas-Fuenmayor 2008). This species has been found from sea level to 1,300 m above sea level.
useTrade: This species is locally eaten and is sold in markets throughout Mexico and Central America, where it is believed to have medicinal value (Savage 2002).
conservationActions: This species is found in several protected areas across its range. Further monitoring of this species is needed, especially to determine if harvest levels are increasing.

rationale: The species is endemic to the Great Bahama Bank, where it occurs on many islands and cays, and therefore has an extent of occurrence (EOO) well above the threshold for a threatened listing under criterion B1 and occurs in numerous locations and it is not considered to be severely fragmented. The number of mature individuals of the species is inferred to be declining as a result of direct persecution and road mortality throughout most of its range; however, population reductions are not known to approach 30% decline over the last 15 years or anticipated to do so over the coming 15 years (= three generations). Research regarding population trends is considered a high priority for the species, and if these reveal substantial declines, reassessment would become urgent.
habitat: This species is found primarily in mesic habitats, but also occurs in xeric situations. It has been found in pinewoods, dry forests, mangroves, shrublands, and gardens. It has a size-dependent ontogenetic dietary shift; small individuals eat Anolis lizards while larger ones are generalists and feed on endo- and exothermic prey. It has viviparous reproduction, and reproduces biennially (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Poaching was historically a severe threat (e.g., almost extirpating the species from Bimini; Tolson and Henderson 1993), and is ongoing (e.g., an individual was confiscated in Nassau Airport - A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015). Persecution is severe, and some subpopulations are threatened road mortality and/or urbanization and tourism development. Cats predate the species throughout its range.
population: The species is moderately difficult to detect under survey effort: it is nocturnal and lives in crevices, rock walls, underground, in treetops, under buildings, and in roofs. No data exist on the extent or trends of the species' population. The species was apparently near-extirpated from Bimini through poaching up until the 1970s, but it seems to have recovered subsequent to the establishment of CITES (R.G. Reynolds and A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to the Great Bahama Bank in the Bahamas (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: The species is common in the pet trade, primarily supplied by captive bred individuals (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2015).
conservationActions: This species is included in CITES Appendix II (under the name Epicrates striatus), the Bahamas Wild Animals (Protection) Act (1968) and the Wildlife Conservation and Trade Act (2004). It occurs in a number of protected areas. The Bahamas National Trust and Ardastra Gardens, Zoo and Conservation Centre are implementing public education and awareness regarding the species on New Providence. Priority conservation actions include education to reduce persecution, invasive species control, and research into the species' population, ecology, and threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited, the species is common, the population trend appears to be stable, the impact of threats presently appears to be limited, and it occurs in three protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in dry to mesic forest, pastureland with isolated trees, residential areas, and disturbed forest. It perches on trees, bushes and other elevated sites from near the ground to about 3 m, with adult individuals displacing juveniles from trees (Ruibal and Philibosian 1974, Henderson and Powell 2009). It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Introduced Puerto Rican ameivas (Pholidoscelis exsul) may represent a potential localized threat as this species has been documented to prey on anole eggs (Treglia et al. 2013), and is an effective active forager that will also take lizards (R. Platenburg pers. comm. 2019). This species was initially restricted around Christansted on St. Croix but appears to have expanded its range, although it is not yet present islandwide (R. Platenburg pers. comm. 2019). The species is also subject to predation by long-established invasive species, principally cats (R. Platenburg pers. comm. 2019). Although this species is a generalist and adapts well to environmental change, the impacts of possible threats from human activities have not been studied (R. Platenburg pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is abundant throughout its range. There is no sign of population decline, although this common species has not been the subject of targeted research (R. Platenburg pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to St. Croix Bank in the U.S. Virgin Islands (Henderson and Powell 2009). It occurs on St. Croix, Buck Island, Green Cay, and Protestant Cay at elevations from sea level to 355 m.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in the Buck Island National Monument and Green Cay and Sandy Point National Wildlife Refuges. No other species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable due to its limited distribution (with an extent of occurrence estimated of 3,581 km<sup>2</sup>), occurrence within a small number of locations (the exact number being uncertain, but treated here as fewer than 10), and it is subject to ongoing threats from expanding agricultural activities, charcoal production and wood harvesting that continue to reduce its area of occupancy and quality of habitat.
habitat: This species is found in shaded broadleaf forest, gallery forest, and shade-grown coffee plantations, where it is often seen along forest edges. It occurs primarily in bushes, shrubs and low-lying vegetation. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: This species requires cool shady habitat with significant tree cover. Although it is found in several protected areas and is tolerant of moderate levels of habitat disturbance (e.g., it is found along road cuts and in shade coffee plantations), it is threatened by the elimination of the cloud forest habitats that removes shade-providing vegetation in many parts of its range due to small-scale agriculture, charcoal production and wood harvesting (L. Mahler, M. Landestoy, S. Inchaustegui pers. comm. 2015).
population: Population density estimates at several sites range from 1,479 to 21,499 lizards/ha (Cast et al. 2000, Sifers et al. 2001). The population trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain: although subpopulations at well-protected sites are inferred to be stable overall there are declines due to severe deforestation, including some in protected areas.
range: This species is endemic to Hispaniola where it occurs in the Sierra de Bahoruco (Dominican Republic) and the Massif de la Selle (Haiti). It has an altitudinal range from about 45 to 1,400 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded to a significant degree.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its distribution, abundance, and population trends should be carried out in order to measure the impact of threats to this species. It occurs in Padre Miguel Fuerte Loren Wildlife Sanctuary and Sierra de Bahoruco National Park (both in the Dominican Republic), but habitat within the latter is disappearing rapidly due to illegal agricultural and wood harvesting activities. Effective protected area and site management is needed to ensure the survival of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because of its large extent of occurrence, there are no current known threats affecting the species, and it occurs in several protected areas.
habitat: This highly arboreal species is found in forested areas, including broadleaf forest, gallery forest, mangroves, as well as coffee and cacao plantations, and abandoned pastures and gardens. It is often found along streams and is associated with medium to large trees (Henderson and Powell 2009, L. Mahler, pers. comm. 2015). It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Localized threats like deforestation due to agriculture, charcoal production and wood harvesting exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population: This species is readily found where it occurs, although in low numbers, as is typical for large arboreal anoles. The population trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain, but is inferred to be stable due to the persistence of large trees in habitats across its range.
range: This species is endemic to Hispaniola, where it occurs in the Dominican Republic, Isla Saona, and islets in the Bahía de Samaná. It has an elevation range between sea level to about 1,220 m asl  (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: This species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action. It occurs in many protected areas, although in this area this confers little to no protection for the species.

rationale: Although not presently rare or known to be declining, the species has a tiny range (meeting the threshold for Endangered under criterion B1). In the absence of apparent threats, no locations are defined for the species, and while a plausible future threat exists from sea level rise the range is not sufficiently small to warrant listing this species as Vulnerable applying criterion D2. Should a threat from invasive predators be documented, the species would be defined as highly restricted to just two locations - a) Crooked Island, Acklins Island, and associated cays; and b) the Plana Cays - defined based on the occurrence of cats and rats through the former, relative to planned protected area establishment on the latter. As such it is considered to approach the thresholds for both Endangered applying B1 and Vulnerable applying D2, and so is assessed as Near Threatened, but it does not presently appear likely to be in decline.
habitat: This species is found in xeric habitats and house gardens (Henderson and Powell 2009), including coastal scrub on East Plana Cay (A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015).
threats: Development pressure is minimal within the species' range (T. Sanger in litt. to R.G. Reynolds 2015). Invasive predators (rats and cats) may prey on this species (A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015). The species' range is very low-lying (with the highest point within its range being approximately 35 m), and so sea level rise may become a threat in the future.
population: The species is common to abundant in all habitat types, and observable day and night, based on observations from 2012 (T. Sanger in litt. to R.G. Reynolds 2015).
range: This species is endemic to the Bahamas where it occurs on the Crooked-Acklins Bank and West Plana Cay and East Plana Cay (Henderson and Powell 2009). It occurs from sea level throughout the island.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The Bahamas National Trust are working to establish a protected area for the Plana Cays (A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015).

rationale: This species has been assessed as Near Threatened because although it has a large extent of occurrence (25,832 km<sup>2</sup>), its distribution is fragmented and it requires moist, shady habitat which is declining in parts of its range due to agriculture expansion, charcoal production and wood harvesting. Although the species is found in a number of protected areas, but most subpopulations are not and this species could qualify for a higher threat level in the near future if habitat loss continues.
habitat: This species is found in moist, shaded woods. It is associated with gallery forest and ravines; also in coffee and cacao plantations. In areas with reduced forest cover, it can sometimes be observed in trees adjacent to rivers and streams or in large fig trees, although always in habitats with significant shade (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015). It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: This species is locally threatened by habitat loss due to agricultural expansion, charcoal production and wood harvesting.
population: This species is reported to be abundant in appropriate habitat (Fläschendräger and Wijfells 2009), although at many sites across its range, it is locally rare (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015). The population is presumed to be declining due to habitat loss.
range: This species is endemic to Hispaniola where it occurs on mountain slopes in both Haiti and Dominican Republic. It has a disjunct range in the Cordillera Central (Massif du Norde in Haiti) and Cordillera Septentrional, as well as a record in the Cordillera Oriental (Henderson and Powell 2009). Its elevational range is 75 m to 1,300 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its distribution, abundance, and population trends should be carried out in order to measure the impact of threats to this species. It is found in several protected areas, however, effective protected area management is needed to ensure the survival of this and other species on Hispaniola.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to its restricted distribution (with an extent of occurrence 710 km<sup>2</sup>), its occurrence as a severely fragmented population, and threats from ongoing and planned future development projects as well as competitive displacement by a common native anole. The species does occur in some protected areas, but the majority of the range is subject to these threats. Monitoring is needed to better understand population trends.
habitat: This species is found in subtropical dry forest (Jezkova et al. 2009). It can occur in disturbed areas such as roadsides, and rural gardens. Individuals perch on rocks and shrubs. The diet is apparently unknown. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: This species is threatened by development for housing and commercial areas. Although this is not a forest obligate and can persist in disturbed areas, the displacement of this species into anthropogenic habitats exposes it to direct competition with Anolis cristatellus. This species has been found to be a superior competitor in these habitats in both field observations and experiments (Jenssen et al. 1984, Genet 2002). Genet (2002) found that A. cookii was "very rare" in sites where the two species co-occurred.
population: The density of this species has been estimated at 36–198 individuals/ha in surveys conducted in 1997 and 1998, although this was based on a total sample of 76 individuals across the entire survey area and period (Genet et al. 2002). This author found that subpopulations at her three study sites were strongly biased towards adult and subadult males (78% of all individuals), suggesting that recruitment is likely to be low at least in these subpopulations. The population trend is unknown, although it has been suggested based on this low rate of recruitment that it "may be declining towards eventual extinction" (Genet 2002). The species' population may be severely fragmented partially as a result of competitive exclusion: Genet et al. (2002) found Anolis cooki at only three of thirteen survey sites, where it occurred in small forest fragments or isolated coastal localities.
range: This species is endemic to Puerto Rico, where it occurs on the southwestern part of the main island, Isla Caja de Muertos, and other satellites (Henderson and Powell 2009, Powell and Henderson 2012). The elevational range is from sea level to approximately 100 m asl (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is listed as an Endangered Species by the Puerto Rican Department of Natural Resources. It occurs in several protected areas (e.g., Guanica and Boquerón State Forests). The species should be monitored to track the effect of development on the population, and its long-term survival is considered to rely on active conservation management (Genet et al. 2002).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is somewhat limited (with an extent of occurrence of 7,475 km<sup>2</sup>), it is locally common. Although habitat destruction is taking place within the range, it is presently considered localized and the species is abundant in a number of protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in secondary tropical moist forest, elfin forest, and coffee plantations. Adults are primarily canopy dwellers while juveniles can be found in lower strata. It feeds on invertebrates such as insects and slugs, plant material including fruits and seeds, other lizards, mice, and nestling birds. It is an oviparous species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: As a canopy species this species is threatened by any activity that removes forest canopy, although it can persist in exotic plantations. Within its range, housing developments and highway construction are the major factors but are considered localized within this lizard's range.
population: This species is reasonably abundant for a large anole. It is locally common especially in El Yunque National Forest, Gambalacha State Forest, and Mata de Plátano Field Station and Nature Reserve. Densities range from 1.3 to 74 individuals per hectare (Henderson and Powell 2009). There is no indication of a widespread decline in the species.
range: This species is known only from mainland Puerto Rico. It has an elevational range from sea level to 1,192 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in numerous protected areas. There are no other species specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although recent taxonomic changes have determined that it has a much more restricted range than previously understood, it is abundant and adaptable to habitat modification within its range as long as some vegetation remains.
habitat: This ubiquitous species perches on trunks and low vegetation in a wide variety of habitats ranging from xeric coastal scrub to montane rainforest. It is also found in abandoned pastures and gardens, agricultural areas and human habitations. It feeds on insects and arachnids and exhibits oviparous reproduction (Henderson and Powell 2009). It appears to exhibit a preference for disturbed areas such as villages as long as trees and bushes survive to provide shade and humidity (Köhler et al. 2019).
threats: Less than 1% of Haiti's original forest cover remains and the country is projected to lose all remaining forest cover within the next two decades (Hedges et al. 2018), as a consequence of impacts from agriculture, logging for charcoal production and attendant soil erosion. This species is nevertheless apparently tolerant of even heavy disturbance, and remains abundant in villages where shade-producing vegetation is retained.
population: This species is abundant.
range: This species is endemic to Hispaniola, where its range appears to be restricted to the western portion of the Tiburon Peninsula from 1 to 780 m asl. (Köhler et al. 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded to any significant degree.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern because it is highly tolerant of habitat alteration.

rationale: The species is assessed as Least Concern based on its wide distribution within Jamaica, tolerance of disturbed habitats, and high population density.
habitat: This species is found in xeric and mesic habitats ranging from open, dry areas to dark forest; including rainforest, xeric coastal woods, secondary growth, gardens and human habitations. It has a broad diet composed of insects, spiders, occasional conspecifics and small fruits. It is an oviparous species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: No threats seem to be causing overall population reductions to the species at this time (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015).
population: The species is common and does not appear to be declining (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015).
range: This Antillean species is endemic to Jamaica where it occurs island-wide, from sea level to ~1,200m (Henderson and Powell 2009, Powell and Henderson 2012).
useTrade: The species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: Specific conservation actions are not presently needed for this species, as it is able to thrive in gardens, small-scale diversified agricultural plots and other human-modified habitats, as well as in natural forest habitats. This species occurs in a number of protected areas, although some of these areas nonetheless experience substantial illicit habitat degradation (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015). There are four subspecies presently recognized (Henderson and Powell 2009), and the species exhibits phenotypic variation across its range. This might suggest the presence of cryptic species (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although its distribution and area of occupancy are limited, it is locally abundant, the population appears to be stable, there are no current threats, and it is tolerant of moderate habitat disturbance.
habitat: This species is found island-wide from the wooded karst regions of the bluff on the eastern end of Cayman Brac, to the more open coastal areas (Henderson and Powell 2009). Unlike other Cayman Island anoles, it spends more time on the ground and in limestone crevices (Grant 1940). It also can be found around buildings and on introduced vegetation, such as coconut palms (A.C. Echternacht pers. comm. 2015).
threats: No major threats are known.
population: This species is locally abundant, and its abundance appears to have been relatively stable over at least the past 10 years.
range: This Antillean species is endemic to Cayman Islands, where it is restricted to Cayman Brac (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Collection of endemic species is regulated by the Cayman Island National Conservation Law (2013); while this species is not presently of commercial interest, this general protection would extend to it. It also occurs within the Brac Parrot Reserve.

rationale: The species is assessed as Least Concern. Despite having an extent of occurrence of <20,000 km<sup>2</sup>, it has a wide distribution within Jamaica, is tolerant of disturbed habitats, and occurs at a high population density.
habitat: This species occurs primarily in the shaded portions of bushy or forested areas, but can occupy open areas within forests (Floyd and Jenssen 1983). It can also occur in Musa groves, and is common near and in human habitations (Russell and Bauer 1991, Henderson and Powell 2009). The species is arboreal but may be saxicolous where suitable habitat occurs (Russell and Bauer 1991). It feeds on a variety of invertebrates and has oviparous reproduction (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: No threats seem to be causing overall population reductions to the species at this time (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015).
population: The species' population is apparently stable, due to occupation of disturbed habitat; and large, due to the availability of suitable habitat throughout its broad distribution across Jamaica (B. Wilson and D.L. Mahler pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to Jamaica where it occurs island-wide. It occurs from sea level to above 1,500 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: The species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: Specific conservation actions are not presently needed for this species, as it is able to thrive in small-scale diversified agricultural plots, as well as in natural forest habitats. This species occurs in a number of protected areas, although some of these areas nonetheless experience substantial illicit habitat degradation (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015). Taxonomic boundaries in this species might need additional characterization (Jackman et al. 2002; B. Wilson pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The species is endemic to the Great Bahama and Conception Banks, but within this range is common (albeit not abundant) and appears to be stable and tolerant of human impacts. It is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is found in varied xeric habitats throughout the islands on which it occurs, including both native and introduced vegetation. The diet consists of insects, spiders, snails, and plant material. It is an egg-laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: No serious threats are considered to affect the species (A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015).
population: The species is less frequently observed than Anolis sagrei and A. disticus in areas where they co-occur, possibly because of its preference for canopy habitat (A. Buckner pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to the Bahamas where it occurs on the Conception and Great Bahama Banks (Henderson and Powell 2009); it has been introduced around Marsh Harbour (Powell and Henderson 2012) and Little Harbour (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2015) on Abaco, and around Freeport on Grand Bahama (J. Losos pers. comm. 2015). It has two subspecies: Anolis smaragdinus lerneri on the western side of the Great Bahama Bank and A. s. smaragdinus on the east and on Conception.
useTrade: There is no significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species occurs in a number of protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is cosmopolitan and often abundant on Sint Eustatius and in areas of Saba with at least some leaf litter, and while threats are poorly-known it is not thought be subject to major threats at present. Little is known of the species' status on the larger islands St. Kitts and Nevis, however the fact of its survival on these highly degraded islands suggests that the species is highly resilient in the face of human impacts and pressures from invasive species.
habitat: This species inhabits mesic environments within gallery forest, xeric scrub, vegetation pockets of Coccoloba and palms, and human habitations (Powell et al. 2005). It is found under rocks, leaf litter, other vegetation debris and human rubble. It seems primarily associated with leaf litter, but persists - although in very low densities - even in extremely inhospitable xeric habitats where vegetation is present. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: It is unknown whether any major threats to this species exist. Development is ongoing within its range, particularly on St. Kitts and Nevis, and introduced species including rats - and, on Kitts and Nevis, mongoose - may depress populations, but the species is not thought to be at immediate risk of extinction.
population: This species appears to reach its highest density on St. Eustatius in leaf litter in the uplands, and is far less abundant elsewhere. In Saba its distribution appears to be patchy and associated with ravines, although it is abundant where it has been observed (Schwartz and Henderson 1991, R. Powell pers. comm. 2015). The latter island's topography precludes much exploration in intervening areas, and it may have a more continuous distribution on this island than known, however these areas also lack many sites where leaf litter can accumulate. Densities of 727 to 1,427 per ha have been recorded in leaf litter at various elevations on St. Eustatius; in highly xeric areas 0-2 animals per Agave plant have been recorded (Hensley et al. 2004), indicating that while these dry habitats are suboptimal the species is rarely truly absent even in hostile environments. There is no indication of population declines.
range: This West Indies species occurs on several islands of the Caribbean Netherlands and Leeward Islands (Henderson and Powell 2009, Powell and Henderson 2012). It is found on the entire St. Kitts Bank and on Saba. This species is thought to occur mostly below 500 m (the highest known sampling localities are at 360 m, where it was still abundant - Hensley et al. 2004), but there may be scattered localities at higher elevations (R. Powell pers, comm. 2015).
useTrade: It is unlikely there is any significant use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (extent of ocurence of 5,200 km<sup>2</sup>), the species is common, the population trend appears to be stable, there are no major threats, and the species occurs in several protected areas.
habitat: This species is from xeric to semi-mesic habitats including coastal palm groves, Cocoloba vegetation pockets and littoral woods. It occurs in secondary forests. Found under rocks, leaf litter, and other vegetation debris. An egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: This species is common within its range, and it is regularly recorded. There is no indication that the population has declined.
range: This West Indies species occurs on Puerto Rico and several satellite islands. Its presence on Isla Culebra is questionable; either the record is in error or its population has been extirpated (Henderson and Powell 2009). The elevation range is from sea level to approximately 200 m.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in several protected areas. There are no specific conservation measures for this species.

rationale: The species is endemic to the Bahamas, and so has a wide range within which it appears to be tolerant of anthropogenic disturbance. It is consequently listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This fossorial species is found from coastal or near-coastal through to more mesic habitats (Domínguez and Díaz 2011), including woodlands, scrublands, cultivated areas, and pastures, where it is found under rocks, rotten logs, and other surface debris. Diet include ants and termites and it has oviparous reproduction (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: No threats are known to face the species in Bahamas. This species has wide habitat tolerances and it is able to adapt to anthropogenic environments.
population: The species is relatively frequently recorded, but there is considerable potential for confusion in the identification of this species compared to the introduced Indotyphlops braminus, and so reports and specimens should be carefully scrutinised (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to the Bahamas, occurring in several islands of Little Bahama Bank and Great Bahama Bank (Domínguez and Díaz 2011). Domínguez and Díaz (2015) resurrect the name Typhlops silus for some specimens collected in eastern Cuba in the first half of the 20th century, which have been previously assigned to T. lumbricalis. These authors do not assign all Cuban records of Typhlops lumbricalis to described Cuban species, and suggest that two undescribed members of this group occur in Cuba, but these are not thought to represent T. lumbricalis sensu stricto.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. However, the range of this species coincides with numerous protected areas. Further research into the taxonomy of this species are recommended for the species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited, there are no current threats, and the entire range is within a protected area. Research is needed to better understand the population size and trend.
habitat: This is a fossorial species that inhabits coastal habitats such as woodlands, Casuarina plantations (Henderson and Powell 2009) and mahogany plantations. It can also be found under rocks and logs. Predators include snowy egrets (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: There are no widespread threats to this species. While cats are present on the island, this species is lives underground and its fossorial lifestyle is thought to offer protection against this invasive predator and cats are not considered a major threat (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2018).
population: This species is infrequently encountered, probably due to its secretive habits. The species was not detected during a week-long visit in July 2015 (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2015). The population size and trend are unknown. However, the habitat where the species occurs is not threatened.
range: This West Indies species is endemic to Isla Mona, Puerto Rico (Henderson and Powell 2009). The elevational range is 0-80 m.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The entire range is within the Mona and Monito Islands Natural Reserve. No specific conservation measures are in place for this species. Research is needed to better understand the population size and trend.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (with an extent of occurrence of 7,420 km<sup>2</sup>), it is abundant, the population trend appears to be stable, there are no current threats, and it occurs in several protected areas.
habitat: This fossorial species inhabits the lowland coastal moist and dry forests. It also occurs in plantations, gardens, and urban areas with vegetation.
threats: At present there are no major threats to this species.
population: This species is fairly abundant within its range. There is no evidence of a population decline. The species has been recorded as recently as 2015 (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species occurs in Puerto Rico and satellite islands. It occurs in the northern, eastern, and southeastern coastal regions of mainland Puerto Rico. This species also occurs on the islands of Palominos, Piñeros, and Vieques (Hedges and Thomas 1991). The elevation ranges from sea level to approximately 450 m.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in several protected areas such as Cerro Pandura Natural Reserve, Cambalache State Forest, and Vieques Wildlife Refuge.

rationale: This species is distributed across Jamaica and can be found in various habitats. It is not being impacted by any major threats and is not undergoing significant declines.
habitat: This species can be found in various habitats in xerophilic to mesophilic environments. It occurs in wooded areas, clearings, pastures, cocoa plantations and along roads cut through forest, and in urban backyards (B. Wilson pers. comm. 2015). It is found under rocks and rotten logs.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threat is impacting on this species.
population: This species is common throughout the whole of Jamaica. Low capture levels are thought to be associated with low levels of surface activity rather than low population density.
range: This species is found throughout the island of Jamaica with an apparently disjunct distribution at elevations from sea level to about 600 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009). The total area of Jamaica is 10,911 km². G.C. Mayer and A. Haynes Sutton (pers. comms.) report that a specimen of Typhlops, very similar to this species, was found on one of the Morant Cays, on the Morant Bank, south of Jamaica. If this specimen is confirmed as T. jamaicensis, then it would significantly extend the EOO of this species.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place, or needed, for this species. In places its distribution coincides with protected areas. Taxonomic research could yield interesting results.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be in decline. If the northern and southern ranges are split into two species, each should be re-assessed.
habitat:
This species occurs in mature deciduous and evergreen forest, secondary forest, and in gardens and plantations (Emmons and Freer 1997, Reid 1997).

It is a lowland tropical forest species that feeds on palm (Attalea butyraceae), and is an important seed disperser (Wright and Duber 2001). It is diurnal; activity starts early in the morning and continues on and off throughout the day. It is sometimes seen at night as it is easily disturbed when sleeping, and it may continue feeding after sunset. It sleeps in hollow logs, under buttress roots, or in tangles of vegetation. Burrows in banks may be used in some regions. Each individual has several sleeping sites that are used repeatedly. The diet consists mainly of seeds and fruits; small amounts of plant material and fungi are included when supplies of fruit are low. When food is abundant, it carries seeds away and buries them for future use, depositing each seed in a different place. Since not all seeds are recovered, this rodent is an important seed disperser for a number of tree species including Guapinol (Hymenaea courabil) (Hallwachs 1986).

Agoutis live in stable pairs that remain together until one of the pair dies. Often only one individual may be seen, as members of the pair do not stay in close contact with each other. Pairs maintain territories but are fairly tolerant of other agoutis if food is plentiful. In aggressive interactions, the long rump hairs are raised to form a fan-shaped crest. Females give birth to 1 or 2 well-developed young. Soon after birth, the mother leads the young to a small nest hole. Young are independent at 4 to 5 months (Reid 1997).
threats: It is a preferred game species (Wright and Duber 2001). This agouti is heavily hunted for meat, and populations are much reduced in many areas with suitable habitat (Emmons and Freer 1997, Reid 1997). It is reluctant to leave its territory and so can be run to ground by dogs and killed with machetes (Reid 1997). In the northern portion of its range, this species is also threatened by habitat loss (conversion to pasture) (Emmons and Freer 1997).
population: This rodent is widespread, and is one of the most common species throughout most of its range (Emmons and Freer 1997, Reid 1997).
range: This species is widespread in Mesoamerica and South America, and has a disjunct range. The northern portion of the range occurs from Chiapas and the Yucatan Peninsula (southern Mexico) to northern Ecuador and Colombia and western Venezuela in the Sierra de Perija and western slopes of the Sierra de Merida to south along the Pacific Coast of Colombia and Ecuador. Extends onto the eastern slope of the eastern Andes in Colombia and into the headwaters of the Rio Sarare in Venezuela (Gilbert 2016, Patton and Emmons 2015). In South America, it is found from sea level up to at least 1,600 m (Patton and Emmons 2015).
conservationActions: This species is listed under CITES Appendix III in Honduras. Guyana had a CITES Annual Export Quota of 350 live animals for 2001. In Panama it is listed as Least Concerned. Occurs in Panamanian national parks and on Panamanian islands.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is found in a broad range of habitats, from Acacia steppe to Valdivian rainforest, and from temperate to cold conditions. Actual limits of distribution appear to be determined by restrictions on the reproductive process, imposed by total annual rainfall in the north and by minimum temperatures in the south (Sallaberry et al. 1981). The species generally occurs in association with breeding sites (temporary or permanent shallow ponds surrounded with swamps and bogs). Northern populations of this species (in Central Chile) live in relictual forests. It may be found in marshes (swamps) of the Nothofagus forest. Males call from under bushes and eggs are laid under logs and in the leaf-litter inside the forest; following rain, the deposition area becomes flooded and larvae develop in water. There is parental care of the eggs by males. It tolerates minor habitat disturbance.
threats: The most impacted sub-populations are those in the north, which are affected by deforestation for cattle ranching, agriculture and human settlements. The species has probably disappeared from many sites in the north described by Sallaberry et al. (1981). Due to its wide distribution, major threats differ between regions, but include many forms of agriculture and wood plantations.
population: It is generally a common species. However, Northern Chilean populations are declining due to habitat destruction.
range: This species is distributed in Chile and Argentina with a wide latitudinal range in the Nothofagus forest region: approximately 1,600 km (Correa et al. 2014). There are fewer records from the northern part of its range (north of Concepción) than from the south, but it seems to be more common than previously thought. Its altitudinal range is from 0-1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs in many national parks and reserves of Chile and Argentina. The species is listed as Near Threatened in Chile (2011). 

Conservation Needed
National legislation to preserve the native forest and environment is needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
habitat: It is typically found in Nothofagus forest, but may also be found in steppe, grassland and transitional zones. It may also be found in urban areas, and in other altered habitats. Adults occur terrestrially in vegetation, below logs and below rocks. It reproduces in all types of waterbodies (although the species generally prefers shallow ponds). Free-swimming larvae characterize it.
threats: There are no major threats to this adaptable species, though a number of sub-populations are impacted by fires, water pollution (by both agriculture and industry) and habitat desiccation due to droughts or land use change.
population: It is a very abundant species within its preferred habitat. This is the most common frog in Chile.
range: This species is widely distributed in Chile from the northern arid territories to the southern Nothofagus forest and from sea level to the vegetation line in the Andes range western slopes of Central Chile. In Argentina, it is widely distributed from the western shore of Laguna Superior de Epulafquen, Departamento Minas (Neuquén) south to the area between La Plata and La Chico lakes, Departamento Río Senguer (Chubut). Its origin is uncertain in Antofagasta, where it has probably been introduced but has not been mapped for this species. It has been introduced in Isla Robinson Crusoe, Archipelago Juan Fernandez. It has an altitudinal range of 0-3,100 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs in many protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It has been reported from many habitats including seasonal, deciduous forest, arid plains and scrubland, grassland, areas of human habitation, plantations, and temporary stagnant wetlands in the breeding season (ponds). Adults are often found under ground cover.
threats: Habitat loss as a result of infrastructure development is the main threat to this frog. It is also threatened by agrochemical pollution and wetland reclamation in Sri Lanka.
population: It is a generally common species through most of its range. It is locally common at Sagaing Wildlife Sanctuary in Myanmar, but is strongly seasonal (Zug et al. 1998). It is regarded to be common in Sri Lanka outside the central hills.
range: This species is widespread throughout South Asia from Pakistan in the west, through India, Nepal and Sri Lanka, to Chitten Wildlife Sanctuary, Sagaing in central Myanmar (Zug et al. 1998). It possibly also occurs in Bangladesh. It is probably more widely distributed through the Irrawady plains but no specific records are available. It has been reported at elevations from sea level up to 1,500 m asl.
conservationActions: It is found in several protected areas within its range. There are no conservation measures needed based on the current understanding of its distribution, taxonomy and population status. It is protected by national legislation in India.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It can be found in mountain forests (broad-leaved and coniferous species) and their surroundings; the forest steppe and even true steppe sites within the mountains. The majority of such populations are the relics of a former forest fauna. Within these landscapes, these populations inhabit slopes and plateau covered with meadows or xerophytic vegetation. Such habitats are especially widespread in the parts of the species' range in Crimea and southern Azerbaijan. In general, T. karelinii seems to be more resistant to xeric habitat conditions than other Triturus newts. Breeding takes place in slow moving stream pools, ponds and occasionally drainage ditches. The female deposits approximately 100-250 eggs; these are individually wrapped in aquatic vegetation. The species can withstand some degree of habitat modification.
threats: Deforestation and pollution of wetlands by agrochemicals appear to be the main threats to this species. In the former Soviet Union there is significant commercial collecting of this species for the pet trade. In Turkey there are no immediate threats to this species, as it is widespread and found in many habitat types. Within Iran it is threatened by urban sprawl along the Caspian coast and foothills, agricultural development (rice cultivation) and logging. In the Balkans, there has been loss of breeding habitats in recent years due to decreased spring rains, perhaps as a result of global climate change. In Greece the loss of aquatic habitats is a serious threat to this species.
population: In West Asia it is reasonably common in suitable habitat. Within the former Soviet Union habitat loss has caused the decline of many populations (especially in the Crimea and the Caucasus).
range: This species ranges from the eastern side of the Balkan Peninsula (extreme southeastern Serbia, eastern FYR Macedonia, most of Bulgaria, northeastern Greece, and European Turkey) through western and northern Turkey along the edges of the Black Sea, to the Caucasus (Russia, Georgia and Azerbaijan). There are apparently isolated populations in central Serbia, on the Crimean Peninsula (Ukraine), and in the southern Caspian region of northern Iran. The map for this species largely follows Arntzen (2003). It can be found from sea level to elevations approaching 2,100 m asl (southern Caucasus).
conservationActions: It is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and on Appendix II of the Bern Convention. It is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and Lists. It is recorded from many protected areas. It is present in the largely protected Hyrcanian Forests of Iran. The species was re-introduced near Sochi Town in Sochi National Park (Russia).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It occurs in a wide variety of habitats including tundra, forest tundra, forest, forest steppe, steppe, forest edges and glades, semi-desert, swamps, peatlands, moorlands, meadows, fields, bush lands, gardens. It has a breeding season, and spawning and larval development takes place in various stagnant water bodies of low acidity, including lakes, ponds, swamps, puddles and ditches. There is some evidence that the species can occur in agricultural landscapes, and in some areas it appears to be adapting to urban conditions (e.g. Vershinin 1997).
threats: It is threatened by the destruction and pollution of breeding ponds (including acidification) and adjacent wetland and terrestrial habitats, especially through urbanization, recreation, tourism, industry and overstocking of cattle. Additional threats are prolonged drought and predation of spawn by waterfowl. Chytrid fungus was detected in this species in Berlin, Germany - however the extent to which this is a threat is unknown.
population: It is generally common, and is abundant in central-eastern Europe. It is extinct in Switzerland in the extreme southwestern part of its wide range. It is considered to be rare and declining in China.
range: This species is found throughout most of the northern, central and eastern parts of Europe, eastwards to Siberia (Yakutia and Baikal Lake), Russia and Xinjiang Province, China. It is no longer believed to be present in Serbia and the original records were probably in error (Kalezic and Dzukic 2001). It is typically a lowland species, but can occur at altitudes close to 1,500 m asl (Altai Mountains).
conservationActions: It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in many countries and has been recorded in a number of national and sub-national Red Data books and lists. It is presumed to be present in a many protected areas. In parts of the species' range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: Many terrestrial (associated with woodland) and aquatic habitat types are used. Present in coniferous, mixed and deciduous forests, forested tundra and steppe, bush and shrublands, glades, grasslands, dry and wet meadows, marshes, fields, rural gardens, parks, and urban areas. Aquatic habitats include both temporary and permanent ponds, lakes and rivers; spawning and larval development occurs in these waterbodies. It does well in many modified habitats such as rural gardens.
threats: There are no major threats to this species. The main localized threat is the general pollution and drainage of breeding sites and wetlands. Over collection for medical research, food and commercial purposes is a threat in parts of its range. Deforestation might have led to a gradual "northward retreat" of the species over southern parts of its distribution. Overcollection for medical research has been a threat in the past, however the extent to which it is a current threat is unknown.
population: It is generally very common, although localized declines have recently been noted in a number of western European countries (e.g. Switzerland, Spain).
range: It is widespread throughout most of Europe, ranging from northern Spain to the Urals (absent from southern and central Iberia, much of southern Italy [scattered Appenine populations] and the Caucasus), and eastwards to the western part of West Siberia and northern Kazakhstan through northern Greece and Bulgaria. It has a patchy distribution in the mountainous parts of the Balkans. Recorded from sea level to elevations approaching 2,700 m asl (Pyrenees).
conservationActions: It is listed on Appendix III of the Berne Convention and on Annex V of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It has been recorded in a number of national and sub-national Red Data books and lists, and is protected by national legislation in a number of countries. It is present in many protected areas. In parts of its range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is a very adaptable opportunist and commensal, occurring from beach vegetation through all manner of human habitats (such as agricultural areas, ditches, artificial ponds and lakes, gardens, even in houses) and natural edge habitats to closed primary forest. It appears to be dependent on human activities to create suitable habitats. There might be separation among habitat axes among the component species in the leucomystax complex.
threats: It is not subjected to any significant degree of disturbance, which could threaten its survival. Presumably heavy application of pesticides around houses might pose threats to local subpopulations. It is sometimes found in the international pet trade but at levels that do not currently constitute a major threat.
population: It is abundant and common throughout its range.
range: This species occurs throughout northeast India and Bangladesh, it is marginal in Nepal, and possibly occurs in Bhutan (although this requires confirmation). It is considered here to be present in western Yunnan, China. It also occurs throughout most of mainland southeast Asia, including islands large (e.g. Phuket (Frith 1977) and Singapore (Lim and Lim 1992, Ming 2000)) and small (e.g. vegetated rocks off Tioman and Redang), and is widespread (and introduced) throughout the Philippines, and is present in Borneo, Mentawai, Sumatra, Java, Sulawesi, Bali, Lombok, Natuna Islands, Anambas Islands, Sumbawa, Sumba, Flores, Timor and is introduced to Papua (not mapped here). It also is found in China. It is introduced to Japan and is found in Okinawajima, Tonakijima, Kurimajima, Miyakojima, Iejima, Iheyajima, Izenajima, Sesokojima and Yabuchijima. It is found up to 1,500 m asl.
conservationActions: The main conservation issue is the cryptic diversity within the species complex as some of the hidden taxa might be of conservation concern, but reliable recognition needs to be established before conservation strategies can be formulated.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is present in deciduous and mixed forests, forest steppe, steppe, bush lands (e.g. riparian alder groves), meadows, fields and fens. It may often be found in shallow stagnant waterbodies (usually without fish) such as lakes, ponds, swamps, large puddles, clay and gravel pits, and ditches, often covered with dense herbaceous vegetation. It breeds in these wetlands, but may be found hibernating away from waterbodies. It is not very adaptable, but can occur in slightly modified habitats.
threats: It is threatened by habitat loss through agricultural intensification and urbanization, channelization of waterbodies, drainage and pollution of wetlands, and the introduction of predatory fishes to breeding sites. It is additionally threatened by afforestation (in northern parts of the range) and competition with the larger sympatric R. ridibunda. The frog-leg trade (which is increasing) and high levels of pollution are leading to significant declines in populations within Yugoslavia (Dzukic 1996, Ljubisavljevic et al. 2003).
population: Although this species is reported to be declining over much of its European range (Gasc et al. 1997), it remains widespread and common in Poland, the Baltic Republics, Moldova, Russia and the Ukraine.
range: This species is distributed over much of Europe, ranging as far east as the southern Ural Mountains of Russia. It is absent from the Iberian Peninsula (except for introductions to Spain in Cáceres [Villasbuenas de Gata] and unspecified localities in Galicia, Cataluña and Comunidad Valenciana), much of Scandinavia, central and southern Italy (exact distribution not known but thought to be replaced by P. bergeri) and it is absent from the Balkans. There are two isolated relict populations - one near Oslo (Norway) and Uppland (Sweden) north of Stockholm. It is native (formerly extirpated) to the British Isles and has been recently reintroduced from Sweden. It might occur up to 1,550 m asl in southern parts of its range.
conservationActions: It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in many countries and is recorded on a number of national and sub-national Red Data books and lists. It is present in many protected areas. In parts of the species' range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

rationale: This species has a very large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend appears to be stable, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size has not been quantified, but it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but the species is described as generally scarce on New Guinea, although locally common; common on New Britain between 900 and 1,500 m and very rare in the Solomon Islands (Gibbs et al. 2001).

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because it has a very small population, which occupies a small range. The species is threatened by introduced and native predators. However, there is no evidence of a decline in the population at present.
habitat: This species frequents mixed scrub, mangroves and Casuarina coastal forest, but prefers to breed in the latter two habitats, perhaps because the taller trees provide better nesting sites (Penny 1974, Stoddart and Westoll 1979, Threadgold and Johnson 1999, Rocamora and Yeatman-Berthelot 2009, Rocamora 2013). Territory size ranges from 2.25 ha in Casuarina woodland to 4.5 ha in mixed scrub (Collar and Stuart 1985, Prys-Jones and Prys-Jones undated). It feeds mainly on a variety of insects and small vertebrates such as geckos, but also has been known to prey on bird eggs, seabird chicks and to cannibalise its own dead offspring (Seychelles Islands Foundation [SIF], unpublished data). Breeding has been recorded between October-November and March-May, and is timed to coincide with the rainy season from December to March (Rocamora and Yeatman-Berthelot 2009). Its nest, in which 1-3 eggs are laid, is a perfectly round cup made from intertwined fine plant fibres bound with spider webs, situated in a fork near the end of a thin horizontal branch, usually 2-8 m above the ground. The species usually nests in trees such as Casuarina equisetifolia, Mystroxylon aethiopicum, Clerodendrum glabrum, Sideroxylon inerme, Cordia subcordata, Euphorbia pyrifolia and mangroves (e.g. Rhizophora mucronata), but also in Ficus spp. in scrub (SIF unpublished data). The incubation period is 16-18 days, followed by a fledging period of 15-19 days. Juvenile birds are dependent for at least several weeks after fledging, and then remain with their parents until at least the following breeding season (François and Fanchette 2003, Rocamora 2013).
threats: It has a high rate of nest failure, probably largely due to introduced native predators (Rocamora and Yeatman-Berthelot 2009, Rocamora 2013, SIF unpublished data). Up to 8/10 studied nests are predated at the egg stage, mainly by crows Corvus spp., rats, coucals and bulbuls (Pycnonotidae), as observed or suggested by nest monitoring (SIF unpublished data) and artificial nest experiments (Rocamora and Jules 2000). There are no known threats to its habitat, but its small island range and population put it at risk from catastrophic events, such as disease or cyclones (Rocamora and Berthelot 2009, Rocamora 2013).
population: In 1983, the total population was estimated to number c.1,500 individuals, equivalent to c.1,000 mature individuals.
range: Dicrurus aldabranus is found on all four main islands of Aldabra Atoll and neighbouring islets, Seychelles (Penny 1974, G. Rocamora in litt. 2008, van de Crommenacker et al. 2015), and also on the larger lagoon islands of Ile Esprit (where breeding has been reported), Ile Moustique, Gros Ilot, Ile Michel and Ile aux Cèdres (Rocamora and Yeatman-Berthelot 2009, Rocamora 2013, A. Skerrett in litt. 1999). Its extent of occurrence is less than 150 km2 (Stoddart and Westoll 1979). In 1983, the total population was estimated at c.1,500 individuals. It is widely distributed but generally uncommon (Stoddart and Westoll 1979).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
Aldabra is protected as a Special Reserve under Seychelles legislation (G. Rocamora in litt. 2008), inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and designated a Ramsar Wetland Site of International Importance(N. Bunbury and A. Burt in litt. 2016). The population has been monitored since 1999 (N. Bunbury and A. Burt in litt. 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Conduct surveys to obtain an up-to-date population estimate. Continue to monitor population trends and nesting success through regular surveys of landbird abundance (van de Crommenacker et al. 2015). Eradicate introduced predators (Rocamora and Yeatman-Berthelot 2009, Rocamora 2013). Protect additional habitat on other islands and islets. Consider translocations to other islands in the Aldabra group (e.g. Assumption) once introduced predators have been removed (N. Bunbury and A. Burt in litt. 2016).

rationale: This species has been downlisted from Endangered following evidence that its population is increasing and is now much larger than previously estimated. It is listed as Near Threatened on the basis that it occupies a tiny range and remains susceptible to stochastic events and the impacts of introduced species, such that it could qualify as threatened within one or two generations.
habitat: It is a territorial insectivore adapted to dense thickets in remaining, largely exotic, vegetation. The low intensity of vegetation cutting by humans appears to promote such dense growth. In 1999, a survey found 78% of the population in habitat dominated by introduced jamrosa Syzygium jambos where the highest densities (2.3 individuals/ha) are found (Showler 1999). The species is also known at lower densities (0.5/ha) in plantations of Swietenia, Tabebuia and Araucaria sp. However other factors, incompletely understood, greatly influence its distribution as demonstrated by the areas of apparently suitable habitat as yet uncolonised (Showler et al. 2002). Restored native forests were found to support the highest densities of the species (Steward 2010). It may breed in groups, as while it usually breeds in pairs there is one report of 4 individuals on a territory, with 3 helping at the nest (Cheke 1987). It lays 3-5 eggs, with the main breeding season September to March (Safford 2013), although only 1-2 chicks may be successfully raised (Safford 2013).
threats: Timber harvesting, subsistence farming and feral livestock have reduced the native habitat to savanna with scattered trees. Currently, the main threat is predation and/or competition from introduced animals such as rats and feral cats (Showler et al. 2002). Sustained periods of drought (reducing invertebrate levels), cyclones, and the destruction and further degradation of remaining suitable habitat are additional problems (Showler et al. 2002). It has survived alongside the Black Rat Rattus rattus for a long time (C. Jones in litt. 2000), but nest predation by this species was believed to be a major factor suppressing its population recovery (Showler et al. 2002). In addition, the fledging success of undisturbed nests appears low, possibly due to food availability (Showler et al. 2002). Human disturbance may be an additional problem at some localities (Showler 1999).
population: In 1999, the population was estimated to be no fewer than 150 individuals, and it remained at this level until 2004 at least (A. Cristinacce and C. Jones in litt. 2005). The population has since risen rapidly to number over 3,000 (3,100-3,900) individuals by 2010 (Steward 2010, C. Jones in litt. 2010, V. Tatayah in litt. 2011) and close to 4,000 by 2012 (V. Tatayah in litt. 2012). The population is therefore estimated at 3,000-4,000 individuals, assumed to include c.2,000-2,700 mature individuals. It has been noted that the current methodology for censusing this species (Showler 2002, Steward 2010) was designed for low population densities and could now over-estimate numbers (P. Steward in litt. 2013).
range: Acrocephalus rodericanus, having once been very common on Rodrigues, Mauritius, declined steadily until 1979, when eight pairs and a singleton were counted (but others probably overlooked). Since 1982, there has been a steady increase in its range (C. Jones in litt. 2000). In 1999, the population was estimated to number at least 150 individuals (Showler 1999, Showler et al. 2002), and surveys up until 2004 suggested there was no change since then (A. Cristinacce and C. Jones in litt. 2005); however, the population has since risen extremely rapidly to number over 3,000 individuals (3,100-3,900) by 2010 (Steward 2010, C. Jones in litt. 2010, V. Tatayah in litt. 2011, 2012).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
Habitat protection and reforestation, spurred by the need for watershed protection, have been key to the recovery of this species, aided by the recent absence of catastrophic cyclones. Much reforestation has involved exotic trees, although native ecosystem rehabilitation has been started at some sites, including nearby islands and the two Conservation Management Areas: Grande Montagne and Anse Quitor (both 0.1 km2). Sites are fenced to exclude grazing animals and woodcutters, exotic plants removed and native species replanted. There has been an accompanying public awareness campaign (Safford 2001). A probable decline in agriculture may have also contributed to habitat availability and the recovery of the species (P. Steward in litt. 2013).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Continue a consistent long-term monitoring programme. Initiate further research into habitat use and breeding success (Showler 1999). Assess the effects of nest predation by introduced species (Showler 1999). Continue rehabilitation of the near-shore island reserves of Ile aux Cocos and Ile aux Sables, plus Anse Quitor (WWF/IUCN 1994, Showler 1999) and Grande Montagne (V. Tatayah in litt. 2012). Investigate the potential of Ile aux Cocos, Ile aux Sables and Anse Quitor to support this species (WWF/IUCN 1994, Showler 1999) and consider translocations if appropriate.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because it has an area of occupancy below 2,000 km2, there is an ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals as a result of competition and predation from invasive species, it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and subpopulations in Guam and Minamitorishima have probably become extinct.
habitat: This species has been collected from palm leaf axils, in shrubs and bushes, and under loose flaking bark on standing trees (Buden 1998). It is apparently highly arboreal and appears to be somewhat adaptable, occurring on islands where the only vegetation consists of coconut and breadfruit trees, as well as in natural forest (A. Allison pers. comm. 2012). It is oviparous.
threats: Displacement by the introduced gecko Hemidactylus frenatus appears to be a serious threat to this species, and has led to substantial declines in abundance most especially in the Marianas Islands (G. Rodda pers. comm. October 2011). This species is probably extinct on Guam through predation by the introduced brown tree snake (Boiga irregularis). It is also food for cats, rats and other introduced predators. This, along with competition from H. frenatus, is presumed to be the cause of its loss from Minamitorishima.  Populations on low-lying atolls are inherently susceptible to increases in sea level.
population: This species does not seem to be uncommon across most of its range, although subpopulations are thought to be declining through much of its range, and due to its occurrence on a series of small islands between which dispersal is not possible, it is considered to occur as a severely fragmented population. In the Marianas Islands it appears to be an uncommon to very rare and localized species, apparently as a result of population declines (G. Rodda pers. comm. October 2011). This species may already have been lost from Minamitorishima, as it was described as being abundant everywhere on the island in 1903 but no individuals were recorded in surveys in 1952 or 2007. It is common on Minamiiwojima, an uninhabited island, and although there is no quantitative data the population is presumed to be stable (Ota 2014).
range: This species is distributed throughout the Marianas Islands (including Guam, where it is now presumed to be extinct); the Federated States of Micronesia, where it is present on about a third of the islands (including Yap, Truk, Chuuk, Pohnpei, Kosrae, Kapingamarangi Atoll); and the Marshall Islands. It is also known from Minamitorishima (= Marcus Island) and Minamiiwozima, Japan  (Ota 2014). These islands have a combined land area of 2,035 km<sup>2</sup>. and the species' area of occupancy is consequently undoubtedly below 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. It is likely most common below 200 m but may range up to 500 m asl.
useTrade: This species is not used or in trade.
conservationActions: Minamiiwojima is designated as a natural monument by Ministry of Environment, Japan, and landing is restricted (Ota 2014). Ex situ conservation and where feasible reintroduction may be important for safeguarding this species, which is secure in only a minority of its range.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, high local population abundance and tolerance to anthropogenic habitats.
habitat: It is found in primary and secondary tropical humid forest, and also occurs in agricultural land and gardens. This species is often found in pseudo-steppe (anthropogenically created grasslands).
threats: There are no major threats to this species and it adapts well to anthropogenic environments. It is sometimes hunted for food. Wood harvesting and agriculture may be localised threats.
population: This species is very abundant, including in urban areas.
range: This species is endemic to Madagascar. It occurs in the eastern and northern parts of the island from sea level to 1,550 m asl.
useTrade: This species is consumed locally.
conservationActions: This species occurs in numerous protected areas including Pic d’Ivohibe, Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve, Mantadia National Park, Ranomafana National Park, Masoala National Park, Andringitra National Park, and Analamazaotra Special Reserve.

rationale: Its area of occupancy (AOO) and extent of occurrence (EOO) are 55 km<sup>2 </sup>and 317 km<sup>2 </sup>respectively, meeting the threshold for the Endangered category, and there is ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat outside protected areas. However, it is an abundant species with a presumed large population and occurs primarily within areas where threats are actively managed. The species does not therefore meet all the required criteria to be listed as Endangered and it has, therefore, been listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: It is a species of fynbos heath land, and in the dry season individuals have been found aestivating under stones or logs and among the roots of dead reed-like plants in dried up watercourses. It typically breeds in seasonally inundated fynbos.
threats: The Cape peninsula is under huge pressure from urban development, the draining of wetlands and invasive alien plants. This species is found primarily within protected areas where all of these threats are actively managed.
population: It is locally abundant where it occurs in aquatic habitats throughout the Cape peninsula, but is absent from artificial habitats, including impoundements and garden ponds, which make up most of the freshwater sites within its extent of occurrence (J. Measey pers. comm. March 2016). All of the sites from which it is known have a protected status.
range: This species is distributed in the southwestern Western Cape Province in South Africa, along the Cape Peninsula. Based on genetics, the currently known easternmost limit is at Kenilworth Racecoarse and Rondevlei (Channing et al. 2013). It is a low altitude species, its EOO is 317 km2 and its AOO is estimated to be 55 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in several protected areas in the Cape Floral Region.

Research Needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread and common, with an apparently stable population, and is subject to only localized threats.
habitat: This is an arboreal and diurnal lizard, that occurs on the trunks of trees in native forest, as well as coconut palms, eucalyptus and similar vegetation (O'Shea et al. 2015).
threats: West Timor is largely denuded, and it has presumably declined here. This is a dry island where fires set from slash and burn agriculture can destroy swathes of forest, and timber is removed for building materials and fuel, with grassland replacing trees on the resulting bare limestone (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). There is little wide-scale land clearance elsewhere in this species' range and it adapts well to the plantations within its range, so it is not subject to major threats elsewhere.
population: This species appears to be reasonably common in suitable forest and plantation environments (O'Shea et al. 2015) on all islands where it occurs (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). The population is apparently stable where sufficient trees remain (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia and Timor-Leste, where it has been reported from the islands of Timor (but not from neighbouring Ataúro Island - O'Shea et al. 2015), Roti, Alor, Semau and Wetar, and Pantar (the latter a new record - S. Reilly unpubl. data). On Timor, it has been recorded from close to sea level to around 1,177 m asl (O'Shea et al. 2015).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is known to occur in protected areas in Wetar and several in Timor, and it is known to occur in these (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). Taxonomic research is underway on this species (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). Protection of any remaining good habitat in West Timor, which is confined to small fragments, is recommended (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and tolerance of a variety of habitats, including modified environments. Despite some habitat loss and degradation, it is unlikely to be declining significantly across its range.
habitat: This diurnal species inhabits the trunks of large trees in coastal and lowland and hill dipterocarp forest up to approximately 800 m asl (Grismer 2011), and semi-evergreen forest and monsoonal evergreen forest, as well as mangrove and coconut plantations (Chan-ard et al. 2015). It is a canopy-dwelling arboreal species (R. Inger and B. Stuart pers. comm. 2010), living almost exclusively in trees and only coming down to the ground to nest or move between trees (Grismer et al. 2006). It has been found in flatland trees as well as coastal areas (Rogner 1997). A study in 1986 found the species in primary rainforests, cultivated patches, in gardens and on individual isolated palm trees (Grossmann 1986); it can be common on coconut palms (Grismer 2011b). It has also been observed in urban areas (Grismer 2011a). Its diet consists on arthropods, including ants and beetles (Chan-ard et al. 2015), and occasionally centipedes (Grismer 2011a). The species is oviparous. The eggs undergo an incubation period of 69 days (Grossmann 1986). Clutch sizes may include up to 14 eggs and more than one clutch may be produced each year (Das 2002). It has a summer reproductive period (Grismer 2011a). It is almost always found close to the water.
threats: Though this species is impacted by habitat degradation in parts of its range, it is widespread and is not considered to be subject to major threats.
population: This is a common to abundant overall species. Its population appears to be stable.
range: This species inhabits the region south of 15º N in Southeast Asia.
